accendible.definition: Capable of being inflamed or kindled; combustible; inflammable

accension.definition: The act of kindling or the state of being kindled; ignition

accensor.definition: One of the functionaries who light and trim the tapers

accent.definition: A superior force of voice or of articulative effort upon some particular syllable of a word or a phrase, distinguishing it from the others

A mark or character used in writing, and serving to regulate the pronunciation; esp.: (a) a mark to indicate the nature and place of the spoken accent; (b) a mark to indicate the quality of sound of the vowel marked; as, the French accents
Modulation of the voice in speaking; manner of speaking or pronouncing; peculiar or characteristic modification of the voice; tone; as, a foreign accent; a French or a German accent
Stress laid on certain syllables of a verse
A regularly recurring stress upon the tone to mark the beginning, and, more feebly, the third part of the measure
A mark placed at the right hand of a letter, and a little above it, to distinguish magnitudes of a similar kind expressed by the same letter, but differing in value, as y′, y″
To express the accent of (either by the voice or by a mark); to utter or to mark with accent

accented.definition: having the main stress of a word; -- used of syllables
being pronounced with sterss; -- used of syllables

accenting.definition: the act of giving special importance or significance to something

accentor.definition: One who sings the leading part; the director or leader
A genus of European birds (so named from their sweet notes), including the hedge warbler. In America sometimes applied to the water thrushes

accentual.definition: Of or pertaining to accent; characterized or formed by accent

accentually.definition: In an accentual manner; in accordance with accent

accentuate.definition: To pronounce with an accent or with accents
To bring out distinctly; to make prominent; to emphasize
To mark with the written accent

accentuation.definition: Act of accentuating; applications of accent

accept.definition: To receive with a consenting mind (something offered); as, to accept a gift; -- often followed by of
To receive with favor; to approve
To receive or admit and agree to; to assent to; as, I accept your proposal, amendment, or excuse
To take by the mind; to understand; as, How are these words to be accepted?
To receive as obligatory and promise to pay; as, to accept a bill of exchange
In a deliberate body, to receive in acquittance of a duty imposed; as, to accept the report of a committee. [This makes it the property of the body, and the question is then on its adoption.]

acceptability.definition: The quality of being acceptable; acceptableness

acceptable.definition: Capable, worthy, or sure of being accepted or received with pleasure; pleasing to a receiver; gratifying; agreeable; welcome; as, an acceptable present, one acceptable to us

acceptableness.definition: The quality of being acceptable, or suitable to be favorably received; acceptability

acceptably.definition: In an acceptable manner; in a manner to please or give satisfaction

acceptance.definition: The act of accepting; a receiving what is offered, with approbation, satisfaction, or acquiescence; esp., favorable reception; approval; as, the acceptance of a gift, office, doctrine, etc
An assent and engagement by the person on whom a bill of exchange is drawn, to pay it when due according to the terms of the acceptance

An agreeing to terms or proposals by which a bargain is concluded and the parties are bound; the reception or taking of a thing bought as that for which it was bought, or as that agreed to be delivered, or the taking possession as owner
An agreeing to the action of another, by some act which binds the person in law

acceptation.definition: Acceptance; reception; favorable reception or regard; state of being acceptable
The meaning in which a word or expression is understood, or generally received; as, term is to be used according to its usual acceptation

accepter.definition: A person who accepts; a taker
A respecter; a viewer with partiality

acceptilation.definition: Gratuitous discharge; a release from debt or obligation without payment; free remission

access.definition: A coming to, or near approach; admittance; admission; accessibility; as, to gain access to a prince
The means, place, or way by which a thing may be approached; passage way; as, the access is by a neck of land
Increase by something added; addition; as, an access of territory. [In this sense accession is more generally used.]
An onset, attack, or fit of disease
A paroxysm; a fit of passion; an outburst; as, an access of fury

accessarily.definition: In the manner of an accessary

accessary.definition: Accompanying, as a subordinate; additional; accessory; esp., uniting in, or contributing to, a crime, but not as chief actor. See Accessory
One who, not being present, contributes as an assistant or instigator to the commission of an offense

accessibility.definition: The quality of being accessible, or of admitting approach; receptibility

accessible.definition: Easy of access or approach; approachable; as, an accessible town or mountain, an accessible person
Open to the influence of; -- with to

accession.definition: A coming to; the act of acceding and becoming joined; as, a king's accession to a confederacy
Increase by something added; that which is added; augmentation from without; as, an accession of wealth or territory

A mode of acquiring property, by which the owner of a corporeal substance which receives an addition by growth, or by labor, has a right to the part or thing added, or the improvement (provided the thing is not changed into a different species). Thus, the owner of a cow becomes the owner of her calf
The act of coming to or reaching a throne, an office, or dignity; as, the accession of the house of Stuart; -- applied especially to the epoch of a new dynasty
The invasion, approach, or commencement of a disease; a fit or paroxysm

accessorial.definition: Of or pertaining to an accessory; as, accessorial agency, accessorial guilt

accessorily.definition: In the manner of an accessory; auxiliary

accessoriness.definition: The state of being accessory, or connected subordinately

accessory.definition: Accompanying as a subordinate; aiding in a secondary way; additional; connected as an incident or subordinate to a principal; contributing or contributory; said of persons and things, and, when of persons, usually in a bad sense; as, he was accessory to the riot; accessory sounds in music
That which belongs to something else deemed the principal; something additional and subordinate
Anything that enters into a work of art without being indispensably necessary, as mere ornamental parts

acciaccatura.definition: A short grace note, one semitone below the note to which it is prefixed; -- used especially in organ music. Now used as equivalent to the short appoggiatura

accidence.definition: The accidents, of inflections of words; the rudiments of grammar

accident.definition: Literally, a befalling; an event that takes place without one's foresight or expectation; an undesigned, sudden, and unexpected event; chance; contingency; often, an undesigned and unforeseen occurrence of an afflictive or unfortunate character; a casualty; a mishap; as, to die by an accident
A property attached to a word, but not essential to it, as gender, number, case
A point or mark which may be retained or omitted in a coat of arms
A property or quality of a thing which is not essential to it, as whiteness in paper; an attribute
Any accidental property, fact, or relation; an accidental or nonessential; as, beauty is an accident

accidental.definition: Happening by chance, or unexpectedly; taking place not according to the usual course of things; casual; fortuitous; as, an accidental visit
Nonessential; not necessary belonging; incidental; as, are accidental to a play
A property which is not essential; a nonessential; anything happening accidentally
Those fortuitous effects produced by luminous rays falling on certain objects so that some parts stand forth in abnormal brightness and other parts are cast into a deep shadow
A sharp, flat, or natural, occurring not at the commencement of a piece of music as the signature, but before a particular note

accidentality.definition: The quality of being accidental; accidentalness

accidentally.definition: In an accidental manner; unexpectedly; by chance; unintentionally; casually; fortuitously; not essentially

accidentalness.definition: The quality of being accidental; casualness

accipiter.definition: A genus of rapacious birds; one of the Accipitres or Raptores
A bandage applied over the nose, resembling the claw of a hawk

accipitral.definition: Pertaining to, or of the nature of, a falcon or hawk; hawklike

accipitres.definition: The order that includes rapacious birds. They have a hooked bill, and sharp, strongly curved talons. There are three families, represented by the vultures, the falcons or hawks, and the owls

accipitridae.definition: a family of birds consisting of the hawks; -- this family includes the Old World vultures; kites; harriers; and eagles

accipitriformes.definition: in some classifications an alternative name for the Falconiformes

accipitrine.definition: Like or belonging to the Accipitres; raptorial; hawklike

acclaim.definition: To shout; as, to acclaim my joy

acclamation.definition: A shout of approbation, favor, or assent; eager expression of approval; loud applause
A representation, in sculpture or on medals, of people expressing joy
In parliamentary usage, the act or method of voting orally and by groups rather than by ballot, esp. in elections

acclamatory.definition: Pertaining to, or expressing approval by, acclamation

acclimate.definition: To habituate to a climate not native; to acclimatize

acclimation.definition: The process of becoming, or the state of being, acclimated, or habituated to a new climate; acclimatization

acclimatization.definition: The act of acclimatizing; the process of inuring to a new climate, or the state of being so inured

acclimatize.definition: To inure or habituate to a climate different from that which is natural; to adapt to the peculiarities of a foreign or strange climate; said of man, the inferior animals, or plants

acclimature.definition: The act of acclimating, or the state of being acclimated

acclivity.definition: A slope or inclination of the earth, as the side of a hill, considered as ascending, in opposition to declivity, or descending; an upward slope; ascent

acclivous.definition: Sloping upward; rising as a hillside; -- opposed to declivous

accloy.definition: To fill to satiety; to stuff full; to clog; to overload; to burden. See Cloy

accoast.definition: To lie or sail along the coast or side of; to accost

accolade.definition: A ceremony formerly used in conferring knighthood, consisting of an embrace, and a slight blow on the shoulders with the flat blade of a sword
A brace used to join two or more staves

accommodable.definition: That may be accommodated, fitted, or made to agree

accommodableness.definition: The quality or condition of being accommodable

accommodate.definition: To render fit, suitable, or correspondent; to adapt; to conform; as, to accommodate ourselves to circumstances
To bring into agreement or harmony; to reconcile; to compose; to adjust; to settle; as, to accommodate differences, a dispute, etc
To furnish with something desired, needed, or convenient; to favor; to oblige; as, to accommodate a friend with a loan or with lodgings
To show the correspondence of; to apply or make suit by analogy; to adapt or fit, as teachings to accidental circumstances, statements to facts, etc.; as, to accommodate prophecy to events
To adapt one's self; to be conformable or adapted
Suitable; fit; adapted; as, means accommodate to end

accommodating.definition: Affording, or disposed to afford, accommodation; obliging; as an accommodating man, spirit, arrangement

accommodation.definition: The act of fitting or adapting, or the state of being fitted or adapted; adaptation; adjustment; -- followed by to

Whatever supplies a want or affords ease, refreshment, or convenience; anything furnished which is desired or needful; -- often in the plural; as, the accommodations -- that is, lodgings and food -- at an inn
An adjustment of differences; state of agreement; reconciliation; settlement
The application of a writer's language, on the ground of analogy, to something not originally referred to or intended

accommodator.definition: He who, or that which, accommodates

accompanier.definition: He who, or that which, accompanies

accompaniment.definition: That which accompanies; something that attends as a circumstance, or which is added to give greater completeness to the principal thing, or by way of ornament, or for the sake of symmetry

accompanist.definition: The performer in music who takes the accompanying part

accompany.definition: To go with or attend as a companion or associate; to keep company with; to go along with; -- followed by with or by; as, he accompanied his speech with a bow
To associate in a company; to keep company
To perform an accompanying part or parts in a composition

accompanyist.definition: a person who provides musical accompaniment (usually on a piano)

accomplice.definition: An associate in the commission of a crime; a participator in an offense, whether a principal or an accessory

accompliceship.definition: The state of being an accomplice

accomplicity.definition: The act or state of being an accomplice

accomplish.definition: To complete, as time or distance
To bring to an issue of full success; to effect; to perform; to execute fully; to fulfill; as, to accomplish a design, an object, a promise
To equip or furnish thoroughly; hence, to complete in acquirements; to render accomplished; to polish

accomplished.definition: Completed; effected; established; as, an accomplished fact
Complete in acquirements as the result usually of training; -- commonly in a good sense; as, an accomplished scholar, an accomplished villain

accomplishment.definition: The act of accomplishing; entire performance; completion; fulfillment; as, the accomplishment of an enterprise, of a prophecy, etc
That which completes, perfects, or equips thoroughly; acquirement; attainment; that which constitutes excellence of mind, or elegance of manners, acquired by education or training

accord.definition: Agreement or concurrence of opinion, will, or action; harmony of mind; consent; assent
Harmony of sounds; agreement in pitch and tone; concord; as, the accord of tones
Agreement, harmony, or just correspondence of things; as, the accord of light and shade in painting
Voluntary or spontaneous motion or impulse to act; -- preceded by own; as, of one's own accord
An agreement between parties in controversy, by which satisfaction for an injury is stipulated, and which, when executed, bars a suit
To make to agree or correspond; to suit one thing to another; to adjust; -- followed by to
To bring to an agreement, as persons; to reconcile; to settle, adjust, harmonize, or compose, as things; as, to accord suits or controversies
To grant as suitable or proper; to concede; to award; as, to accord to one due praise
To agree; to correspond; to be in harmony; -- followed by with, formerly also by to; as, his disposition accords with his looks
To agree in pitch and tone

accordant.definition: Agreeing; consonant; harmonious; corresponding; conformable; -- followed by with or to

accordantly.definition: In accordance or agreement; agreeably; conformably; -- followed by with or to

accorder.definition: One who accords, assents, or concedes

according.definition: Agreeing; in agreement or harmony; harmonious

accordingly.definition: Agreeably; correspondingly; suitably; in a manner conformable

accordion.definition: A small, portable, keyed wind instrument, whose tones are generated by play of the wind upon free metallic reeds

accorporate.definition: To unite; to attach; to incorporate

accost.definition: To join side to side; to border; hence, to sail along the coast or side of
To approach; to make up to
To speak to first; to address; to greet

accosted.definition: Supported on both sides by other charges; also, side by side

accoucheur.definition: A man who assists women in childbirth; a man midwife; an obstetrician

account.definition: A reckoning; computation; calculation; enumeration; a record of some reckoning; as, the Julian account of time

A registry of pecuniary transactions; a written or printed statement of business dealings or debts and credits, and also of other things subjected to a reckoning or review; as, to keep one's account at the bank

A statement in general of reasons, causes, grounds, etc., explanatory of some event; as, no satisfactory account has been given of these phenomena. Hence, the word is often used simply for reason, ground, consideration, motive, etc.; as, on no account, on every account, on all accounts
A statement of facts or occurrences; recital of transactions; a relation or narrative; a report; a description; as, an account of a battle
A statement and explanation or vindication of one's conduct with reference to judgment thereon
An estimate or estimation; valuation; judgment
To reckon; to compute; to count
To place to one's account; to put to the credit of; to assign; -- with to
To value, estimate, or hold in opinion; to judge or consider; to deem
To render or receive an account or relation of particulars; as, an officer must account with or to the treasurer for money received
To render an account; to answer in judgment; -- with for; as, we must account for the use of our opportunities
To give a satisfactory reason; to tell the cause of; to explain; -- with for; as, idleness accounts for poverty

account book.definition: A book in which accounts are kept

accountability.definition: The state of being accountable; liability to be called on to render an account; the obligation to bear the consequences for failure to perform as expected; accountableness

accountable.definition: Liable to be called on to render an account; answerable; as, every man is accountable to God for his conduct
Capable of being accounted for; explicable

accountable ness.definition: The quality or state of being accountable; accountability

accountancy.definition: The art or employment of an accountant

accountant.definition: One who renders account; one accountable
One who is skilled in, keeps, or adjusts, accounts; an officer in a public office, who has charge of the accounts

accountantship.definition: The office or employment of an accountant

accouplement.definition: The act of coupling, or the state of being coupled; union
That which couples, as a tie or brace

accouter.definition: To furnish with dress, or equipments, esp. those for military service; to equip; to attire; to array

accoutered.definition: provided with necessary articles of equipment for a specialized purpose especially military; as, troops accoutered for battle

accouterments.definition: Dress; trappings; equipment; specifically, the devices and equipments worn by soldiers

accoutrement.definition: an item of clothing that is worn or carried, but not part of one's main clothing

accoy.definition: To subdue; to tame; to daunt

accra.definition: The capital city of Ghana.  Population (2000) = nk

accredit.definition: To put or bring into credit; to invest with credit or authority; to sanction
To send with letters credential, as an ambassador, envoy, or diplomatic agent; to authorize, as a messenger or delegate
To believe; to credit; to put trust in
To credit; to vouch for or consider (some one) as doing something, or (something) as belonging to some one

accreditation.definition: The act of accrediting; as, letters of accreditation

accrementition.definition: The process of generation by development of blastema, or fission of cells, in which the new formation is in all respects like the individual from which it proceeds

accrete.definition: To adhere; to grow (to); to be added; -- with to
Characterized by accretion; made up; as, accrete matter

accretion.definition: The act of increasing by natural growth; esp. the increase of organic bodies by the internal accession of parts; organic growth
The act of increasing, or the matter added, by an accession of parts externally; an extraneous addition; as, an accretion of earth
Concretion; coherence of separate particles; as, the accretion of particles so as to form a solid mass
A growing together of parts naturally separate, as of the fingers or toes

The adhering of property to something else, by which the owner of one thing becomes possessed of a right to another; generally, gain of land by the washing up of sand or soil from the sea or a river, or by a gradual recession of the water from the usual watermark

accretive.definition: Relating to accretion; increasing, or adding to, by growth

accroach.definition: To hook, or draw to one's self as with a hook
To usurp, as jurisdiction or royal prerogatives

accrue.definition: To come to by way of increase; to arise or spring as a growth or result; to be added as increase, profit, or damage, especially as the produce of money lent

accruer.definition: The act of accruing; accretion; as, title by accruer

accrument.definition: The process of accruing, or that which has accrued; increase

accubation.definition: The act or posture of reclining on a couch, as practiced by the ancients at meals

accumbency.definition: The state of being accumbent or reclining

accumbent.definition: Leaning or reclining, as the ancients did at their meals
Lying against anything, as one part of a leaf against another leaf

accumulate.definition: To heap up in a mass; to pile up; to collect or bring together; to amass; as, to accumulate a sum of money
To grow or increase in quantity or number; to increase greatly

accumulated.definition: brought together into a group or crowd

accumulation.definition: The act of accumulating, the state of being accumulated, or that which is accumulated; as, an accumulation of earth, of sand, of evils, of wealth, of honors
The concurrence of several titles to the same proof

accumulative.definition: Characterized by accumulation; serving to collect or amass; cumulative; additional

accumulator.definition: One who, or that which, accumulates, collects, or amasses

An apparatus by means of which energy or power can be stored, such as the cylinder or tank for storing water for hydraulic elevators, the secondary or storage battery used for accumulating the energy of electrical charges, etc
A system of elastic springs for relieving the strain upon a rope, as in deep-sea dredging

accuracy.definition: The state of being accurate; freedom from mistakes, this exemption arising from carefulness; exact conformity to truth, or to a rule or model; precision; exactness; nicety; correctness; as, the value of testimony depends on its accuracy

accurate.definition: In exact or careful conformity to truth, or to some standard of requirement, the result of care or pains; free from failure, error, or defect; exact; as, an accurate calculator; an accurate measure; accurate expression, knowledge, etc
Precisely fixed; executed with care; careful

accurately.definition: In an accurate manner; exactly; precisely; without error or defect

accurateness.definition: The state or quality of being accurate; accuracy; exactness; nicety; precision

accurse.definition: To devote to destruction; to imprecate misery or evil upon; to curse; to execrate; to anathematize

accursed.definition: Doomed to destruction or misery; cursed; hence, bad enough to be under the curse; execrable; detestable; exceedingly hateful; -- as, an accursed deed

accusable.definition: Liable to be accused or censured; chargeable with a crime or fault; blamable; -- with of

accusation.definition: The act of accusing or charging with a crime or with a lighter offense
That of which one is accused; the charge of an offense or crime, or the declaration containing the charge

accusative.definition: Applied to the case (as the fourth case of Latin and Greek nouns) which expresses the immediate object on which the action or influence of a transitive verb terminates, or the immediate object of motion or tendency to, expressed by a preposition. It corresponds to the objective case in English

accusatively.definition: In relation to the accusative case in grammar

accusatory.definition: Pertaining to, or containing, an accusation; as, an accusatory libel

accuse.definition: To charge with, or declare to have committed, a crime or offense
To charge with a fault; to blame; to censure

accused.definition: Charged with offense; as, an accused person

accuser.definition: One who accuses; one who brings a charge of crime or fault

accustom.definition: To make familiar by use; to habituate, familiarize, or inure; -- with to

ace.definition: A unit; a single point or spot on a card or die; the card or die so marked; as, the ace of diamonds
Hence: A very small quantity or degree; a particle; an atom; a jot
A single point won by a stroke, as in handball, rackets, etc.; in tennis, frequently, a point won by a service stroke

synonyms: Syn. -- A-one, first-class, first-rate, super, tip-top, topnotch(predicate)

ace.definition: to get a grade of "A"; as, to ace an exam

acedia.definition: apathy and inactivity in the practice of virtue (personified as one of the deadly sins)

aceldama.definition: The potter's field, said to have lain south of Jerusalem, purchased with the bribe which Judas took for betraying his Master, and therefore called the field of blood. Fig.: A field of bloodshed

acellular.definition: not made up of or divided into cells
occurring outside of cells or without the participation of cells.  Opposite of cellular

acephala.definition: That division of the Mollusca which includes the bivalve shells, like the clams and oysters; -- so called because they have no evident head. Formerly the group included the Tunicata, Brachiopoda, and sometimes the Bryozoa. See Mollusca

acephali.definition: A fabulous people reported by ancient writers to have heads
A Christian sect without a leader
A class of levelers in the time of K. Henry I

acephalist.definition: One who acknowledges no head or superior

acephalocyst.definition: A larval entozoön in the form of a subglobular or oval vesicle, or hydatid, filled with fluid, sometimes found in the tissues of man and the lower animals; -- so called from the absence of a head or visible organs on the vesicle. These cysts are the immature stages of certain tapeworms. Also applied to similar cysts of different origin

acephalocystic.definition: Pertaining to, or resembling, the acephalocysts

acephalous.definition: Without a distinct head; -- a term applied to bivalve mollusks
Having the style spring from the base, instead of from the apex, as is the case in certain ovaries
Deficient at the beginning, as a line of poetry

acequia.definition: A canal or trench for irrigating land

acer.definition: type genus of the Aceraceae; trees or shrubs having winged fruit

aceraceae.definition: the family of trees including the maples

acerate.definition: A combination of aceric acid with a salifiable base

acerb.definition: Sour, bitter, and harsh to the taste, as unripe fruit; sharp and harsh

acerbate.definition: To sour; to imbitter; to irritate

acerbity.definition: Sourness of taste, with bitterness and astringency, like that of unripe fruit
Harshness, bitterness, or severity; as, acerbity of temper, of language, of pain

aceric.definition: Pertaining to, or obtained from, the maple; as, aceric acid

acerose.definition: Having the nature of chaff; chaffy

acerous.definition: Destitute of tentacles, as certain mollusks

acervate.definition: Heaped, or growing in heaps, or closely compacted clusters

acervative.definition: Heaped up; tending to heap up

acescence.definition: The quality of being acescent; the process of acetous fermentation; a moderate degree of sourness

acescent.definition: Turning sour; readily becoming tart or acid; slightly sour
A substance liable to become sour

acetable.definition: An acetabulum; or about one eighth of a pint

acetabulifera.definition: The division of Cephalopoda in which the arms are furnished with cup-shaped suckers, as the cuttlefishes, squids, and octopus; the Dibranchiata. See Cephalopoda

acetabuliferous.definition: Furnished with fleshy cups for adhering to bodies, as cuttlefish, etc

acetabuliform.definition: Shaped like a shallow cup; saucer-shaped; as, an acetabuliform calyx

acetabulum.definition: A vinegar cup; socket of the hip bone; a measure of about one eighth of a pint, etc
The bony cup which receives the head of the thigh bone

acetal.definition: A limpid, colorless, inflammable liquid from the slow oxidation of alcohol under the influence of platinum black

acetamide.definition: A white crystalline solid, from ammonia by replacement of an equivalent of hydrogen by acetyl

acetaminophen.definition: a white crystalline compound (HO.C6H4.NH.CO.CH3) used as an analgesic and also as an antipyretic. It has molecular weight 151.16.  It is the active ingredient in the commercial analgesics Tylenol and Datril
synonyms: Syn. -- p-hydroxyacetanilide, p-acetamidophenol, N-acetyl-p-aminophenol, paracetamol, N-(4-hydroxyphenyl)acetamide

acetanilide.definition: An amide formed from aniline and an acetyl group (C6H5.NH.CO.CH3); it is a white crystalline compound used as an analgesic and also as an antipyretic.  It has molecular weight 135.16
synonyms: Syn. -- phenylacetamide, N-phenylacetamide, antifebrin, antifebrine, acetylaminobenzene, acetylaniline

acetarious.definition: Used in salads; as, acetarious plants

acetary.definition: An acid pulp in certain fruits, as the pear

acetate.definition: A salt formed by the union of acetic acid with a base or positive radical; as, acetate of lead, acetate of potash

acetic.definition: Of a pertaining to vinegar; producing vinegar; producing vinegar; as, acetic fermentation

acetification.definition: The act of making acetous or sour; the process of converting, or of becoming converted, into vinegar

acetify.definition: To convert into acid or vinegar

acetimeter.definition: An instrument for estimating the amount of acetic acid in vinegar or in any liquid containing acetic acid

acetimetry.definition: The act or method of ascertaining the strength of vinegar, or the proportion of acetic acid contained in it

acetin.definition: A combination of acetic acid with glycerin

acetol.definition: Methyl ketol; also, any of various homologues of the same
a trade name used at different times to represent different substances, as hydroxyacetone, acetylsalicylic acid, acetal, diethyl aldehyde, or cellulose acetate

acetone.definition: A volatile liquid (CH3.CO.CH3); pyroacetic spirit; methyl ketone; -- obtained by fermentation, the distillation of certain acetates, or by the destructive distillation of citric acid, starch, sugar, or gum, with quicklime.   It is commonly used as a solvent

acetonemia.definition: A morbid condition characterized by the presence of ketone bodies (including acetone, acetoacetic acid and beta-hydroxybutyric acid) in the blood, as in diabetes

acetonic.definition: Of or pertaining to acetone; as, acetonic bodies

acetonuria.definition: Excess of ketone bodies (including acetone, acetoacetic acid and beta-hydroxybutyric acid) in the urine, as in starvation or diabetes

acetophenetidin.definition: A white crystalline compound used as an analgesic and also as an antipyretic

acetophenone.definition: A crystalline ketone, CH3.CO.C6H5, which may be obtained by the dry distillation of a mixture of the calcium salts of acetic and benzoic acids. It is used as a hypnotic under the name of hypnone

acetosity.definition: The quality of being acetous; sourness

acetous.definition: Having a sour taste; sour; acid
Causing, or connected with, acetification; as, acetous fermentation

acetphenetidin.definition: a white crystalline compound used as an analgesic and also as an antipyretic

acetyl.definition: A complex, hypothetical radical, composed of two parts of carbon to three of hydrogen and one of oxygen. Its hydroxide is acetic acid

acetylate.definition: receive substitution of an acetyl group; of chemical compounds
introduce an acetyl group into a chemical compound

acetylcholine.definition: a neurotransmitter released by the transmitting dendron at autononmous synapses and at neuromuscular junctions.  It is a quaternary amine with an obligatory negative counterion.  The nominal formula for the hydroxide form is C7H17NO3.  Structural formula (CH3)3N(+)CH2CH2.O.CO.CH3.OH(-)

acetylcholinesterase.definition: an enzyme which exists in nerve cells and hydrolyses acetylcholine into choline and acetic acid

acetylene.definition: A gaseous compound of carbon and hydrogen, in the proportion of two atoms of the former to two of the latter. It is a colorless gas, with a peculiar, unpleasant odor, and is produced for use as an illuminating gas in a number of ways, but chiefly by the action of water on calcium carbide. Its light is very brilliant

ach.definition: A name given to several species of plants; as, smallage, wild celery, parsley

achaean.definition: Of or pertaining to Achaia in Greece; also, Grecian

achatina.definition: A genus of land snails, often large, common in the warm parts of America and Africa

ache.definition: Continued pain, as distinguished from sudden twinges, or spasmodic pain. “Such an ache in my bones.”
To suffer pain; to have, or be in, pain, or in continued pain; to be distressed

achene.definition: A small, dry, indehiscent fruit, containing a single seed, as in the buttercup; -- called a naked seed by the earlier botanists

acheron.definition: A river in the Nether World or infernal regions; also, the infernal regions themselves. By some of the English poets it was supposed to be a flaming lake or gulf

acherontic.definition: Of or pertaining to Acheron; infernal; hence, dismal, gloomy; moribund

acheta.definition: a genus of Orthopteran insects consisting of common house and field crickets

achievability.definition: the possibility of being achieved or accomplished; -- a property which may be possessed by a contemplated act

achieve.definition: To carry on to a final close; to bring out into a perfected state; to accomplish; to perform; -- as, to achieve a feat, an exploit, an enterprise
To obtain, or gain, as the result of exertion; to succeed in gaining; to win

achievement.definition: The act of achieving or performing; an obtaining by exertion; successful performance; accomplishment; as, the achievement of his object
A great or heroic deed; something accomplished by valor, boldness, or praiseworthy exertion; a feat
An escutcheon or ensign armorial; now generally applied to the funeral shield commonly called hatchment

achillean.definition: Resembling Achilles, the hero of the Iliad; invincible

achilles.definition: a mythical Greek hero of the Iliad; a foremost Greek warrior at the seige of Troy

achilles' tendon.definition: The strong tendon formed of the united tendons of the large muscles in the calf of the leg, an inserted into the bone of the heel; -- so called from the mythological account of Achilles being held by the heel when dipped in the River Styx

achimenes.definition: any plant of the genus Achimenes having gloxinialike flowers

aching.definition: That aches; continuously painful. See Ache

achiote.definition: Seeds of the annotto tree; also, the coloring matter, annotto

achlamydate.definition: Not possessing a mantle; -- said of certain gastropods

achlamydeous.definition: Naked; having no floral envelope, neither calyx nor corolla

achondroplasia.definition: A skeletal disorder beginning before birth; cartilage is converted to bone resulting in dwarfism

achras.definition: A genus of tropical trees having papery leaves and large fruit

achromatic.definition: Free from color; transmitting light without decomposing it into its primary colors
Uncolored; not absorbing color from a fluid; -- said of tissue

achromatin.definition: Tissue which is not stained by fluid dyes

achromatinic.definition: not readily colored by stains; -- of substance of a cell nucleus

achromatism.definition: The state or quality of being achromatic; as, the achromatism of a lens; achromaticity

achromatization.definition: The act or process of achromatizing

achromatize.definition: To deprive of color; to make achromatic

achromatopsy.definition: Color blindness; inability to distinguish colors; Daltonism

achromatous.definition: Lacking, or deficient in, color; as, achromatous blood

achromic.definition: Free from color; colorless; as, in (Physiol. Chem.), the achromic point of a starch solution acted upon by an amylolytic enzyme is the point at which it fails to give any color with iodine

achroodextrin.definition: Dextrin not colorable by iodine. See Dextrin

acicula.definition: One of the needlelike or bristlelike spines or prickles of some animals and plants; also, a needlelike crystal

acicular.definition: Needle-shaped; slender like a needle or bristle, as some leaves or crystals; also, having sharp points like needles

acid.definition: Sour, sharp, or biting to the taste; tart; having the taste of vinegar: as, acid fruits or liquors. Also fig.: Sour-tempered
Of or pertaining to an acid; as, acid reaction

One of a class of compounds, generally but not always distinguished by their sour taste, solubility in water, and reddening of vegetable blue or violet colors. They are also characterized by the power of destroying the distinctive properties of alkalies or bases, combining with them to form salts, at the same time losing their own peculiar properties. They all contain hydrogen, united with a more negative element or radical, either alone, or more generally with oxygen, and take their names from this negative element or radical. Those which contain no oxygen are sometimes called hydracids in distinction from the others which are called oxygen acids or oxacids

acid process.definition: That variety of either the Bessemer or the open-hearth process in which the converter or hearth is lined with acid, that is, highly siliceous, material. Opposed to basic process

acid-forming.definition: yielding an acid in aqueous solution

acid-loving.definition: thriving in a relatively acid environment; -- especially of plants requiring a pH well below 7

acid-wash.definition: to wash (blue jeans) in acid, so as to cause the color to fade

acidic.definition: Containing a high percentage of silica; -- opposed to basic
of or relating to acid; having the character of an acid, as an acidic solution

acidifiable.definition: Capable of being acidified, or converted into an acid

acidific.definition: Producing acidity; converting into an acid

acidification.definition: The act or process of acidifying, or changing into an acid

acidifier.definition: A simple or compound principle, whose presence is necessary to produce acidity, as oxygen, chlorine, bromine, iodine, etc

acidify.definition: To make acid; to convert into an acid; as, to acidify sugar

acidimeter.definition: An instrument for ascertaining the strength of acids

acidimetry.definition: The measurement of the strength of acids, especially by a chemical process based on the law of chemical combinations, or the fact that, to produce a complete reaction, a certain definite weight of reagent is required

acidity.definition: The quality of being sour; sourness; tartness; sharpness to the taste; as, the acidity of lemon juice

acidophilic.definition: growing well in an acid medium; said of some bacteria

acidosis.definition: abnormally high acidity of the blood and other body fluids

acidotic.definition: of or pertaining to acidosis; suffering from acidosis

acidulate.definition: To make sour or acid in a moderate degree; to sour somewhat

acidulent.definition: Having an acid quality; sour; acidulous

acidulous.definition: Slightly sour; sub-acid; sourish; as, an acidulous tincture

acierage.definition: The process of coating the surface of a metal plate (as a stereotype plate) with steellike iron by means of voltaic electricity; steeling

acinaceous.definition: Containing seeds or stones of grapes, or grains like them

acinetae.definition: A group of suctorial Infusoria, which in the adult stage are stationary. See Suctoria

aciniform.definition: Having the form of a cluster of grapes; clustered like grapes
Full of small kernels like a grape

acinose.definition: Consisting of acini, or minute granular concretions; as, acinose or acinous glands

acinus.definition: One of the small grains or drupelets which make up some kinds of fruit, as the blackberry, raspberry, etc
One of the granular masses which constitute a racemose or compound gland, as the pancreas; also, one of the saccular recesses in the lobules of a racemose gland

acipenser.definition: A genus of ganoid fishes, including the sturgeons, having the body armed with bony scales, and the mouth on the under side of the head. See Sturgeon

acipenseridae.definition: The natural family of fish including the sturgeons

ack-ack.definition: Artillery designed to shoot upward at airplanes; antiaircraft artillery
synonyms: Syn. -- antiaircraft, antiaircraft gun, flak, pompom, pom-pom, ack-ack gun

ackee.definition: red pear-shaped tropical fruit with poisonous seeds; its flesh is poisonous when unripe or overripe

acknowledge.definition: To own or admit the knowledge of; to recognize as a fact or truth; to declare one's belief in; as, to acknowledge the being of a God
To own or recognize in a particular character or relationship; to admit the claims or authority of; to give recognition to
To own with gratitude or as a benefit or an obligation; as, to acknowledge a favor, the receipt of a letter
To own as genuine; to assent to, as a legal instrument, to give it validity; to avow or admit in legal form; as, to acknowledge a deed

acknowledged.definition: Generally accepted or recognized as correct or reasonable.  Opposite of unacknowledged

acknowledgment.definition: The act of acknowledging; admission; avowal; owning; confession
The act of owning or recognizing in a particular character or relationship; recognition as regards the existence, authority, truth, or genuineness; a statement acknowledging something or someone
The owning of a benefit received; courteous recognition; the state or quality of being recognized or acknowledged; an expression of thanks
Something given or done in return for a favor, message, etc
A declaration or avowal of one's own act, to give it legal validity; as, the acknowledgment of a deed before a proper officer. Also, the certificate of the officer attesting such declaration

aclinic.definition: Without inclination or dipping; -- said of the imaginary line near the earth's equator on which the magnetic needle balances itself horizontally, having no dip.  The aclinic line is also termed the magnetic equator

acme.definition: The top or highest point; the culmination
The crisis or height of a disease
Mature age; full bloom of life

acne.definition: Inflammation of the sebaceous glands that are associated with hair follicles, leading to visible comedones and pimples, especially on the face, back, and chest

acnode.definition: An isolated point not upon a curve, but whose coördinates satisfy the equation of the curve so that it is considered as belonging to the curve

synonyms: Syn. -- Akocanthera, genus Acocanthera, genus Acokanthera.

acock.definition: In a cocked or turned up fashion

acockbill.definition: Hanging at the cathead, ready to let go, as an anchor

acokanthera.definition: small genus of trees and shrubs containing strongly toxic cardiac glycosides; distributed from Arabia to Africa
synonyms: Syn. -- Acocanthera, genus Acocanthera, genus Acokanthera

acology.definition: Materia medica; the science of remedies

acolyctine.definition: An organic base, in the form of a white powder, obtained from Aconitum lycoctonum

acolyte.definition: One who has received the highest of the four minor orders in the Catholic church, being ordained to carry the wine and water and the lights at the Mass

aconite.definition: The herb wolfsbane, or monkshood; -- applied to any plant of the genus Aconitum (tribe Hellebore), all the species of which are poisonous
An extract or tincture obtained from Aconitum napellus, used as a poison and medicinally

aconitic.definition: Pert. to or designating a crystalline tribasic acid, C6H6O6, obtained from aconite and other plants. It is a carboxyl derivative of itaconic acid.  Both the natural forma from plants and the form prepared chemically have the trans-configuration.  It is used in the manufacture of itaconic acid (propylene dicarboxylic acid)
synonyms: Syn. -- 1-propene-1,2,3-tricarboxylic acid, equisetic acid, citridic acid, achilleic acid

aconitine.definition: An intensely poisonous alkaloid, extracted from aconite

aconitum.definition: The poisonous herb aconite; also, an extract from it

acontia.definition: Threadlike defensive organs, composed largely of nettling cells (cnidæ), thrown out of the mouth or special pores of certain Actiniæ when irritated

acontias.definition: Anciently, a snake, called dart snake; now, one of a genus of reptiles closely allied to the lizards

acorn.definition: The fruit of the oak, being an oval nut growing in a woody cup or cupule
A cone-shaped piece of wood on the point of the spindle above the vane, on the mast-head

acorn cup.definition: The involucre or cup in which the acorn is fixed

acorn-shell.definition: One of the sessile cirripeds; a barnacle of the genus Balanus. See Barnacle

acosmism.definition: A denial of the existence of the universe as distinct from God

acosmist.definition: One who denies the existence of the universe, or of a universe as distinct from God

acotyledon.definition: A plant which has no cotyledons, as the dodder and all flowerless plants

acotyledonous.definition: Having no seed lobes, as the dodder; also applied to plants which have no true seeds, as ferns, mosses, etc

acouchy.definition: A small species of agouti (Dasyprocta acouchy)

acoumeter.definition: An instrument for measuring the acuteness of the sense of hearing

acoumetry.definition: The measuring of the power or extent of hearing

acoustic.definition: Pertaining to the sense of hearing, the organs of hearing, or the science of sounds; auditory
A medicine or agent to assist hearing

acoustically.definition: In relation to sound or to hearing

acoustics.definition: The science of sounds, teaching their nature, phenomena, and laws

acquaint.definition: To furnish or give experimental knowledge of; to make (one) to know; to make familiar; -- followed by with
To communicate notice to; to inform; to make cognizant; -- followed by with (formerly, also, by of), or by that, introducing the intelligence; as, to acquaint a friend with the particulars of an act

acquaintable.definition: Easy to be acquainted with; affable

acquaintance.definition: A state of being acquainted, or of having intimate, or more than slight or superficial, knowledge; personal knowledge gained by intercourse short of that of friendship or intimacy; as, I know the man; but have no acquaintance with him
A person or persons with whom one is acquainted

acquaintanceship.definition: A state of being acquainted; acquaintance

acquainted.definition: Personally known; familiar. See To be acquainted with, under Acquaint, v. t

acquaintedness.definition: State of being acquainted; degree of acquaintance

acquest.definition: Property acquired by purchase, gift, or otherwise than by inheritance

acquiesce.definition: To rest satisfied, or apparently satisfied, or to rest without opposition and discontent (usually implying previous opposition or discontent); to accept or consent by silence or by omitting to object; -- followed by in, formerly also by with and to
To concur upon conviction; as, to acquiesce in an opinion; to assent to; usually, to concur, not heartily but so far as to forbear opposition

acquiescence.definition: A silent or passive assent or submission, or a submission with apparent content; -- distinguished from avowed consent on the one hand, and on the other, from opposition or open discontent; quiet satisfaction
Submission to an injury by the party injured

acquiescency.definition: The quality of being acquiescent; acquiescence

acquiescent.definition: Resting satisfied or submissive; disposed tacitly to submit; assentive; as, an acquiescent policy

acquirability.definition: The quality of being acquirable; attainableness

acquire.definition: To gain, usually by one's own exertions; to get as one's own; as, to acquire a title, riches, knowledge, skill, good or bad habits

acquired.definition: gotten through environmental forces.  Contrasted with inherited

acquirement.definition: The act of acquiring, or that which is acquired; attainment

acquisition.definition: The act or process of acquiring
The purchase of one commercial enterprise by another, whether for cash, or in a trade of stock of the purchasing company for that of the purchased company
The thing acquired or gained; an acquirement; a gain; as, learning is an acquisition

acquisitive.definition: Able or disposed to make acquisitions; acquiring; as, an acquisitive person or disposition

acquisitiveness.definition: The quality of being acquisitive; propensity to acquire property; desire of possession
The faculty to which the phrenologists attribute the desire of acquiring and possessing

acquit.definition: To discharge, as a claim or debt; to clear off; to pay off; to requite
To pay for; to atone for

To set free, release or discharge from an obligation, duty, liability, burden, or from an accusation or charge; -- now followed by of before the charge, formerly by from; as, the jury acquitted the prisoner; we acquit a man of evil intentions

acquittal.definition: The act of acquitting; discharge from debt or obligation; acquittance
A setting free, or deliverance from the charge of an offense, by verdict of a jury or sentence of a court

acquittance.definition: The clearing off of debt or obligation; a release or discharge from debt or other liability
A writing which is evidence of a discharge; a receipt in full, which bars a further demand

acrania.definition: Partial or total absence of the skull
The lowest group of Vertebrata, including the amphioxus, in which no skull exists

acraspeda.definition: A group of acalephs, including most of the larger jellyfishes; the Discophora

acre.definition: Any field of arable or pasture land

A piece of land, containing 160 square rods, or 4,840 square yards, or 43,560 square feet. This is the English statute acre. That of the United States is the same. The Scotch acre was about 1.26 of the English, and the Irish 1.62 of the English

acreable.definition: Of an acre; per acre; as, the acreable produce

acreage.definition: Acres collectively; as, the acreage of a farm or a country

acred.definition: Possessing acres or landed property; -- used in composition; as, large-acred men

acrid.definition: Sharp and harsh, or bitter and not, to the taste; pungent; as, acrid salts
Causing heat and irritation; corrosive; as, acrid secretions
Caustic; bitter; bitterly irritating; as, acrid temper, mind, writing

acridity.definition: The quality of being acrid or pungent; irritant bitterness; extreme bitterness; acrimony; as, the acridity of a plant, of a speech

acridotheres.definition: a genus of birds comprising the mynas

acrimonious.definition: Caustic; bitter-tempered' sarcastic; as, acrimonious dispute, language, temper

acrimoniousness.definition: The quality of being acrimonious; asperity; acrimony

acrimony.definition: A quality of bodies which corrodes or destroys others; also, a harsh or biting sharpness; as, the acrimony of the juices of certain plants
Sharpness or severity, as of language or temper; irritating bitterness of disposition or manners

acrita.definition: The lowest groups of animals, in which no nervous system has been observed

acritan.definition: Of or pertaining to the Acrita

acritical.definition: Having no crisis; giving no indications of a crisis; as, acritical symptoms, an acritical abscess

acroamatic.definition: Communicated orally; oral; -- applied to the esoteric teachings of Aristotle, those intended for his genuine disciples, in distinction from his exoteric doctrines, which were adapted to outsiders or the public generally. Hence: Abstruse; profound

acrobat.definition: One who practices rope dancing, high vaulting, or other daring gymnastic feats

acrobatism.definition: Feats of the acrobat; daring gymnastic feats; high vaulting

acrocarpous.definition: Having a terminal fructification; having the fruit at the end of the stalk

acroceraunian.definition: Of or pertaining to the high mountain range of “thunder-smitten” peaks (now Kimara), between Epirus and Macedonia

acroclinium.definition: a genus of herbs and shrubs of Australia and Southern Africa, with an everlasting flower; most species are usually placed in genus Helipterum

acrocomia.definition: a genus of Central and South American feather palms

acrodactylum.definition: The upper surface of the toes, individually

acrodont.definition: One of a group of lizards having the teeth immovably united to the top of the alveolar ridge

acrogen.definition: A plant of the highest class of cryptogams, including the ferns, etc. See Cryptogamia

acrogenic.definition: pertaining to acrogens, flowerless plants (ferns or mosses) in which growth occurs only at the tip of the main stem

acrogenous.definition: Increasing by growth from the extremity; as, an acrogenous plant

acrolein.definition: A limpid, colorless, highly volatile liquid, obtained by the dehydration of glycerin, or the destructive distillation of neutral fats containing glycerin. Its vapors are intensely irritating

acrolith.definition: A statue whose extremities are of stone, the trunk being generally of wood

acrolithan.definition: Pertaining to, or like, an acrolith

acromegaly.definition: Chronic enlargement of many bones of the skeleton, especially bones of hands, feet and face; the condition is due to excessive secretion of growth hormone

acromial.definition: Of or pertaining to the acromion

acromion.definition: The outer extremity of the shoulder blade

acromonogrammatic.definition: Having each verse begin with the same letter as that with which the preceding verse ends

acronyc.definition: Rising at sunset and setting at sunrise, as a star; -- opposed to cosmical

acronycally.definition: In an acronycal manner as rising at the setting of the sun, and vice versa

acropetal.definition: Developing from below towards the apex, or from the circumference towards the center; centripetal; -- said of certain inflorescence

acrophony.definition: The use of a picture symbol of an object to represent phonetically the initial sound of the name of the object

acropodium.definition: The entire upper surface of the foot

acropolis.definition: The upper part, or the citadel, of a Grecian city; especially, the citadel of Athens

acrospire.definition: The sprout at the end of a seed when it begins to germinate; the plumule in germination; -- so called from its spiral form
To put forth the first sprout

acrospore.definition: A spore borne at the extremity of the cells of fructification in fungi

across.definition: From side to side; athwart; crosswise, or in a direction opposed to the length; quite over; as, a bridge laid across a river
From side to side; crosswise; as, with arms folded across

synonyms: Syn. -- all-embracing, all-inclusive, blanket(prenominal), broad, complete, global, panoptic, wide

acrostic.definition: A composition, usually in verse, in which the first or the last letters of the lines, or certain other letters, taken in order, form a name, word, phrase, or motto
A Hebrew poem in which the lines or stanzas begin with the letters of the alphabet in regular order (as Psalm cxix.). See Abecedarian
Pertaining to, or characterized by, acrostics

acrostically.definition: After the manner of an acrostic

acrotarsium.definition: The instep or front of the tarsus

acroteleutic.definition: The end of a verse or psalm, or something added thereto, to be sung by the people, by way of a response

acroterial.definition: Pertaining to an acroterium; as, acroterial ornaments

acroterium.definition: One of the small pedestals, for statues or other ornaments, placed on the apex and at the basal angles of a pediment. Acroteria are also sometimes placed upon the gables in Gothic architecture

acrotic.definition: Pertaining to or affecting the surface of the body

acrotomous.definition: Having a cleavage parallel with the base

acrylic.definition: Of or containing acryl, the hypothetical radical (R.CH:CH.CO-) of which acrolein (H2C:CH.CHO) is the hydride; as, acrylic acid.  The characteristic residue in an acrylic compound is the carbonyl group attached directly to an ethylenic carbon
Of or pertaining to a derivative of acrylic acid, or an object consisting mostly of an acrylic resin; as, an acrylic window
A paint in which the pigment is suspended in a solution of an acrylic resin, which dries to a hard film on exposure to air
A painting made using an acrylic paint; as, he donated several of his acrylics to the museum

acrylic resin.definition: a thermoplastic made by polymerization of acrylic acid or methacrylic acid or some derivative of these (such as the esters or amides).  It can be formed into a clear hard plastic, and is the basis for the commercial plastics called Lucite and Plexiglass

acrylonitrile.definition: a colorless liquid compound (H2C:CH.CN); used as raw material for acrylic fibers, and as a solvent

act.definition: That which is done or doing; the exercise of power, or the effect, of which power exerted is the cause; a performance; a deed

The result of public deliberation; the decision or determination of a legislative body, council, court of justice, etc.; a decree, edit, law, judgment, resolve, award; as, an act of Parliament, or of Congress
A state of reality or real existence as opposed to a possibility or possible existence
Process of doing; action. In act, in the very doing; on the point of (doing)
To move to action; to actuate; to animate
To perform; to execute; to do
To perform, as an actor; to represent dramatically on the stage
To assume the office or character of; to play; to personate; as, to act the hero
To feign or counterfeit; to simulate
To exert power; to produce an effect; as, the stomach acts upon food
To perform actions; to fulfill functions; to put forth energy; to move, as opposed to remaining at rest; to carry into effect a determination of the will
To behave or conduct, as in morals, private duties, or public offices; to bear or deport one's self; as, we know not why he has acted so
To perform on the stage; to represent a character

acth.definition: a growth hormone produced by the anterior pituitary gland; stimulates the adrenal cortex
synonyms: Syn. -- adrenocorticotropic hormone, adrenocorticotrophic hormone, adrenocorticotropin, adrenocorticotrophin, corticotropin, corticotrophin

actinal.definition: Pertaining to the part of a radiate animal which contains the mouth

actinaria.definition: An order of Anthozoa, including those which have simple tentacles and do not form stony corals. Sometimes, in a wider sense, applied to all the Anthozoa, expert the Alcyonaria, whether forming corals or not

acting.definition: Doing duty for another; officiating; as, an   acting superintendent

actinia.definition: An animal of the class Anthozoa, and family Actinidæ.  From a resemblance to flowers in form and color, they are often called animal flowers and sea anemones. [See Polyp.]

actinian.definition: any sea anemone or related animal

synonyms: Syn. -- order Actiniaria, Actinaria, order Actinaria

actiniarian.definition: any sea anemone or related animal

actinic.definition: Of or pertaining to actinism; as, actinic rays

actinidia.definition: a small Asiatic woody vine bearing many-seeded fruit

actinidiaceae.definition: tropical trees or shrubs or woody vines

actiniform.definition: Having a radiated form, like a sea anemone

actiniopteris.definition: a genus of terrestrial ferns of tropical Asia and Africa

actinism.definition: The property of radiant energy (found chiefly in solar or electric light) by which chemical changes are produced, as in photography

actinium.definition: A supposed metal, said by Phipson to be contained in commercial zinc; -- so called because certain of its compounds are darkened by exposure to light

actino-chemistry.definition: Chemistry in its relations to actinism

actinogram.definition: A record made by the actinograph

actinograph.definition: An instrument for measuring and recording the variations in the actinic or chemical force of rays of light

actinoid.definition: Having the form of rays; radiated, as an actinia

actinolite.definition: A bright green variety of amphibole occurring usually in fibrous or columnar masses

actinolitic.definition: Of the nature of, or containing, actinolite

actinology.definition: The science which treats of rays of light, especially of the actinic or chemical rays

actinomere.definition: One of the radial segments composing the body of one of the Cœlenterata

actinometer.definition: An instrument for measuring the direct heating power of the sun's rays

actinometric.definition: Pertaining to the measurement of the intensity of the solar rays, either (a) heating, or (b) actinic

actinometry.definition: The measurement of the force of solar radiation
The measurement of the chemical or actinic energy of light

actinomycetes.definition: branched gram-positive bacteria, often found in soil, some of which are pathogenic for humans and animals

actinomycin.definition: any of various red antibiotics isolated from soil bacteria with a three-ring heterocyclic nucleus with an attached peptide chain

actinomycin d.definition: The most well-known of the actinomycins (C62H86N12O16), a class of antibiotics which act by binding to DNA and inhibiting synthesis of RNA; they act agains gram-positive bacteria and many eukaryotic organisma.  Actinomycin D has been used in human medicine to treat certain tumors
synonyms: Syn. -- dactinomycin, actinomycin IV, Cosmegen[trade name], actinomycin C1, actinomycin I1

actinomycosis.definition: A chronic infectious disease of cattle and man due to infection with actinomycetes, especially by Actinomyces bovis in cattle and by Actinomyces israeli or Arachnia propionica in man. It is characterized by hard swellings usually in the mouth and jaw. In man the disease may also affect the abdomen or thorax. In cattle it is called also lumpy jaw or big jaw

actinomyxidia.definition: an order comprising parasites of worms

actinomyxidian.definition: a type of parasite of worms

actinophone.definition: An apparatus for the production of sound by the action of the actinic, or ultraviolet, rays

actinophonic.definition: Pertaining to, or causing the production of, sound by means of the actinic, or ultraviolet, rays; as, actinophonic phenomena

actinopod.definition: protozoa having stiff rodlike radiating pseudopods

actinosome.definition: The entire body of a cœlenterate

actinost.definition: One of the bones at the base of a paired fin of a fish

actinostome.definition: The mouth or anterior opening of a cœlenterate animal

actinotrocha.definition: A peculiar larval form of Phoronis, a genus of marine worms, having a circle of ciliated tentacles

actinozoa.definition: A group of Cœlenterata, comprising the Anthozoa and Ctenophora. The sea anemone, or actinia, is a familiar example

actinozoal.definition: Of or pertaining to the Actinozoa

actinula.definition: A kind of embryo of certain hydroids (Tubularia), having a stellate form

action.definition: A process or condition of acting or moving, as opposed to rest; the doing of something; exertion of power or force, as when one body acts on another; the effect of power exerted on one body by another; agency; activity; operation; as, the action of heat; a man of action
An act; a thing done; a deed; an enterprise. (pl.):   Habitual deeds; hence, conduct; behavior; demeanor
The event or connected series of events, either real or imaginary, forming the subject of a play, poem, or other composition; the unfolding of the drama of events
Movement; as, the horse has a spirited action
Effective motion; also, mechanism; as, the breech action of a gun
Any one of the active processes going on in an organism; the performance of a function; as, the action of the heart, the muscles, or the gastric juice
Gesticulation; the external deportment of the speaker, or the suiting of his attitude, voice, gestures, and countenance, to the subject, or to the feelings
The attitude or position of the several parts of the body as expressive of the sentiment or passion depicted

A suit or process, by which a demand is made of a right in a court of justice; in a broad sense, a judicial proceeding for the enforcement or protection of a right, the redress or prevention of a wrong, or the punishment of a public offense
A share in the capital stock of a joint-stock company, or in the public funds; hence, in the plural, equivalent to stocks
An engagement between troops in war, whether on land or water; a battle; a fight; as, a general action, a partial action
The mechanical contrivance by means of which the impulse of the player's finger is transmitted to the strings of a pianoforte or to the valve of an organ pipe

actionable.definition: That may be the subject of an action or suit at law; as, to call a man a thief is actionable

actium.definition: naval battle where Antony and Cleopatra were defeated by Octavian's fleet under Agrippa in 31 BC

activated.definition: treated with aeration and bacteria to aid decomposition; -- of sewage
made reactive or more reactive; -- of e.g. a molecule
rendered active; -- as e.g. radioactive or luminescent or photosensitive or conductive
set up and placed on active assignment

activating.definition: causing motion or action or change

activator.definition: any agency bringing about activation; (Biol.) a molecule that increases the activity of an enzyme or a protein that increases the production of a gene product in DNA transcription

active.definition: Having the power or quality of acting; causing change; communicating action or motion; acting; -- opposed to passive, that receives; as, certain active principles; the powers of the mind
Quick in physical movement; of an agile and vigorous body; nimble; as, an active child or animal
In action; actually proceeding; working; in force; -- opposed to quiescent, dormant, or extinct; as, active laws; active hostilities; an active volcano
Given to action; constantly engaged in action; energetic; diligent; busy; -- opposed to dull, sluggish, indolent, or inert; as, an active man of business; active mind; active zeal
Requiring or implying action or exertion; -- opposed to sedentary or to tranquil; as, active employment or service; active scenes
Given to action rather than contemplation; practical; operative; -- opposed to speculative or theoretical; as, an active rather than a speculative statesman
Brisk; lively; as, an active demand for corn
Implying or producing rapid action; as, an active disease; an active remedy
Applied to a form of the verb; -- opposed to passive. See Active voice, under Voice

actively.definition: In an active manner; nimbly; briskly; energetically; also, by one's own action; voluntarily, not passively
In an active signification; as, a word used   actively

activeness.definition: The quality of being active; nimbleness; quickness of motion; activity

activism.definition: a policy of taking direct and militant action to achieve a political or social goal

activist.definition: one who is aggressively active on behalf of a cause
advocating a cause or engaged in activism

activity.definition: The state or quality of being active; nimbleness; agility; vigorous action or operation; energy; active force; as, an increasing variety of human activities

acton.definition: A stuffed jacket worn under the mail, or (later) a jacket plated with mail

actor.definition: One who acts, or takes part in any affair; a doer
An advocate or proctor in civil courts or causes

actress.definition: A female stageplayer; a woman who acts a part

acts.definition: one of the books of the Christian New Testament describing the activities of Christ's apostles after his death

actual.definition: Existing in act or reality; really acted or acting; in fact; real; -- opposed to potential, possible, virtual, speculative, conceivable, theoretical, or nominal; as, the actual cost of goods; the actual case under discussion
In action at the time being; now exiting; present; as the actual situation of the country
Something actually received; real, as distinct from estimated, receipts

actualisation.definition: A making actual or really existent; giving the appearance of reality

actualist.definition: One who deals with or considers actually existing facts and conditions, rather than fancies or theories; a realist; -- opposed to idealist

actuality.definition: The state of being actual; reality; as, the actuality of God's nature

actualize.definition: To make actual; to realize in action

actualized.definition: changed from potential to actual; as, saw his worst fears actualized

actually.definition: In act or in fact; really; in truth; positively

actuarial.definition: Of or pertaining to actuaries; as, the actuarial value of an annuity

actuary.definition: A registrar or clerk; -- used originally in courts of civil law jurisdiction, but in Europe used for a clerk or registrar generally
The computing official of an insurance company; one whose profession it is to calculate for insurance companies the risks and premiums for life, fire, and other insurances

actuate.definition: To put into action or motion; to move or incite to action; to influence actively; to move as motives do; -- more commonly used of persons
To carry out in practice; to perform

actuating.definition: causing motion or action or change

actuator.definition: One who actuates, or puts into action

acuate.definition: To sharpen; to make pungent; to quicken

acuity.definition: Sharpness or acuteness, as of a needle, wit, etc

aculea.definition: A small spiny outgrowth on the wings of certain insects

aculeate.definition: Having a sting; covered with prickles; sharp like a prickle
Having prickles, or sharp points; beset with prickles

aculeated.definition: Having a sharp point; armed with prickles; prickly; aculeate

aculeolate.definition: Having small prickles or sharp points

aculeus.definition: A prickle growing on the bark, as in some brambles and roses

acumen.definition: Quickness of perception or discernment; penetration of mind; the faculty of nice discrimination

acuminate.definition: Tapering to a point; pointed; as, acuminate leaves, teeth, etc
To end in, or come to, a sharp point

acumination.definition: A sharpening; termination in a sharp point; a tapering point

acuminose.definition: Terminating in a flat, narrow end

acupressure.definition: A mode of arresting hemorrhage resulting from wounds or surgical operations, by passing under the divided vessel a needle, the ends of which are left exposed externally on the cutaneous surface

acupuncture.definition: Pricking with a needle; a needle prick

acute.definition: Sharp at the end; ending in a sharp point; pointed; -- opposed to blunt or obtuse; as, an acute angle; an acute leaf
Having nice discernment; perceiving or using minute distinctions; penetrating; clever; shrewd; -- opposed to dull or stupid; as, an acute observer; acute remarks, or reasoning
Having nice or quick sensibility; susceptible to slight impressions; acting keenly on the senses; sharp; keen; intense; as, a man of acute eyesight, hearing, or feeling; acute pain or pleasure
High, or shrill, in respect to some other sound; -- opposed to grave or low; as, an acute tone or accent
Attended with symptoms of some degree of severity, and coming speedily to a crisis; -- opposed to chronic; as, an acute disease
To give an acute sound to; as, he acutes his rising inflection too much

acute-angled.definition: Having acute angles; as, an acute-angled triangle, a triangle with every one of its angles less than a right angle

acutely.definition: In an acute manner; sharply; keenly; with nice discrimination

acuteness.definition: The quality of being acute or pointed; sharpness; as, the acuteness of an angle

The faculty of nice discernment or perception; acumen; keenness; sharpness; sensitiveness; -- applied to the senses, or the understanding.  By acuteness of feeling, we perceive small objects or slight impressions: by acuteness of intellect, we discern fine distinctions
Shrillness; high pitch; -- said of sounds
Violence of a disease, which brings it speedily to a crisis

acutilobate.definition: Having acute lobes, as some leaves

acutorsion.definition: The twisting of an artery with a needle to arrest hemorrhage

acyclic.definition: Not cyclic; not disposed in cycles or whorls

acyl.definition: An acid radical, as acetyl, malonyl, or benzoyl.  An acyl radical can be depicted as R-CO-, where -CO- is the carbonyl group, and R is the group that characterizes the acyl moiety

ad captandum.definition: A phrase used adjectively sometimes of meretricious attempts to catch or win popular favor

ad hominem.definition: A phrase applied to an appeal or argument addressed to the principles, interests, or passions of a man

ad libitum.definition: At one's pleasure; as one wishes

ad valorem.definition: A term used to denote a duty or charge laid upon goods, at a certain rate per cent upon their value, as stated in their invoice, -- in opposition to a specific sum upon a given quantity or number; as, an ad valorem duty of twenty per cent

ad-.definition: As a prefix ad- assumes the forms ac-, af-, ag-, al-, an-, ap-, ar-, as-, at-, assimilating the d with the first letter of the word to which ad- is prefixed. It remains unchanged before vowels, and before d, h, j, m, v. Examples: adduce, adhere, adjacent, admit, advent, accord, affect, aggregate, allude, annex, appear, etc. It becomes ac- before qu, as in acquiesce

adad.definition: the Babylonian god of storms and wind

adage.definition: An old saying, which has obtained credit by long use; a proverb

adagio.definition: Slow; slowly, leisurely, and gracefully. When repeated, adagio, adagio, it directs the movement to be very slow
A piece of music in adagio time; a slow movement; as, an adagio of Haydn

adam.definition: The name given in the Bible to the first man, the progenitor of the human race

adam-and-eve.definition: North American orchid (Aplectrum hyemale) bearing a single leaf and yellowish-brown flowers

adamant.definition: A stone imagined by some to be of impenetrable hardness; a name given to the diamond and other substances of extreme hardness; but in modern mineralogy it has no technical signification. It is now a rhetorical or poetical name for the embodiment of impenetrable hardness

adamantine.definition: Made of adamant, or having the qualities of adamant; incapable of being broken, dissolved, or penetrated; as, adamantine bonds or chains
Like the diamond in hardness or luster

adambulacral.definition: Next to the ambulacra; as, the adambulacral ossicles of the starfish

adamic.definition: Of or pertaining to Adam, or resembling him

adamite.definition: A descendant of Adam; a human being
One of a sect of visionaries, who, professing to imitate the state of Adam, discarded the use of dress in their assemblies

adansonia.definition: A genus of great trees related to the Bombax.  There are two species, Adansonia digitata, the baobab or monkey-bread of Africa and India, and Adansonia Gregorii, the sour gourd or cream-of-tartar tree of Australia.  Both have a trunk of moderate height, but of enormous diameter, and a wide-spreading head.  The fruit is oblong, and filled with pleasantly acid pulp.  The wood is very soft, and the bark is used by the natives for making ropes and cloth

adapa.definition: a demigod or first man: "seed of mankind"; sometimes identified with Adam

adapid.definition: extinct small mostly diurnal lower primates that fed on leaves and fruit; abundant in North America and Europe 30 to 50 million years ago; their descendents probably include the lemurs and lorises; some authorities consider them ancestral to anthropoids but others consider them only cousins

adapt.definition: To make suitable; to fit, or suit; to adjust; to alter so as to fit for a new use; -- sometimes followed by to or for

adaptability.definition: The quality of being adaptable; suitableness

adaptation.definition: The act or process of adapting, or fitting; or the state of being adapted or fitted; fitness
The result of adapting; an adapted form

adaptational.definition: having a capacity for adaptation.  Opposed to maladaptive

adaptedness.definition: The state or quality of being adapted; suitableness; special fitness

adaptive.definition: Suited, given, or tending, to adaptation; characterized by adaptation; capable of adapting

adaptive optics.definition: an optical system used in some telescopes since the 1980's which rapidly changes the shape of the primary reflecting mirror to adjust for distortions of light which are caused by atmospheric turbulence.  By reducing the distortions caused by the atmosphere, telescopes fitted with such optics can achieve a higher resolving power than normal telescopes with static mirrors

adaptive radiation.definition: the evolutionary generation of multiple specialized life forms from one ancestral form, evidenced in the fossil record.  The inverse of extinction

adaptiveness.definition: The quality of being adaptive; capacity to adapt

adar.definition: The twelfth month of the Hebrew ecclesiastical year, and the sixth of the civil. It corresponded nearly with March

adarce.definition: A saltish concretion on reeds and grass in marshy grounds in Galatia. It is soft and porous, and was formerly used for cleansing the skin from freckles and tetters, and also in leprosy

adatis.definition: A fine cotton cloth of India

adaunt.definition: To daunt; to subdue; to mitigate

adays.definition: By day, or every day; in the daytime

add.definition: To give by way of increased possession (to any one); to bestow (on)

To join or unite, as one thing to another, or as several particulars, so as to increase the number, augment the quantity, enlarge the magnitude, or so as to form into one aggregate. Hence: To sum up; to put together mentally; as, to add numbers; to add up a column
To append, as a statement; to say further
To make an addition. To add to, to augment; to increase; as, it adds to our anxiety
To perform the arithmetical operation of addition; as, he adds rapidly

addax.definition: One of the largest African antelopes (Hippotragusnasomaculatus or Oryx nasomaculatus)

addend.definition: a number that is added to another number

addendum.definition: A thing to be added; an appendix or addition

adder.definition: One who, or that which, adds; esp., a machine for adding numbers
A small venomous serpent of the genus Vipera. The common European adder is the Vipera  berus or Pelias berus. The puff adders of Africa are species of Clotho
