apsis.definition: One of the two points of an orbit, as of a planet or satellite, which are at the greatest and least distance from the central body, corresponding to the aphelion and perihelion of a planet, or to the apogee and perigee of the moon. The more distant is called the higher apsis; the other, the lower apsis; and the line joining them, the line of apsides
In a curve referred to polar coördinates, any point for which the radius vector is a maximum or minimum

apsu.definition: father of the gods and consort of Tiamat

apt.definition: Fit or fitted; suited; suitable; appropriate
Having an habitual tendency; habitually liable or likely; -- used of things
Inclined; disposed customarily; given; ready; -- used of persons
Ready; especially fitted or qualified (to do something); quick to learn; prompt; expert; as, a pupil apt to learn; an apt scholar
To fit; to suit; to adapt

aptera.definition: Insects without wings, constituting the seventh Linnæn order of insects, an artificial group, which included Crustacea, spiders, centipeds, and even worms. These animals are now placed in several distinct classes and orders

apteral.definition: Without lateral columns; -- applied to buildings which have no series of columns along their sides, but are either prostyle or amphiprostyle, and opposed to peripteral

apteria.definition: Naked spaces between the feathered areas of birds. See Pteryliæ

apterous.definition: Destitute of wings; apteral; as, apterous insects
Destitute of winglike membranous expansions, as a stem or petiole; -- opposed to alate

apteryges.definition: An order of birds, including the genus Apteryx

apterygiformes.definition: a ratite bird order: flightless ground birds having vestigial wings and long bills and small eyes: kiwis

apteryx.definition: A genus of New Zealand birds about the size of a hen, with only short rudiments of wings, armed with a claw and without a tail; the kiwi. It is allied to the gigantic extinct moas of the same country. Five species are known

aptitude.definition: A natural or acquired disposition or capacity for a particular purpose, or tendency to a particular action or effect; as, oil has an aptitude to burn
A general fitness or suitableness; adaptation

aptly.definition: In an apt or suitable manner; fitly; properly; pertinently; appropriately; readily

aptness.definition: Fitness; suitableness; appropriateness; as, the aptness of things to their end
Disposition of the mind; propensity; as, the aptness of men to follow example
Quickness of apprehension; readiness in learning; docility; as, an aptness to learn is more observable in some children than in others
Proneness; tendency; as, the aptness of iron to rust

aptote.definition: A noun which has no distinction of cases; an indeclinable noun

aptotic.definition: Pertaining to, or characterized by, aptotes; uninflected; as, aptotic languages

aptychus.definition: A shelly plate found in the terminal chambers of ammonite shells. Some authors consider them to be jaws; others, opercula

apus.definition: A genus of fresh-water phyllopod crustaceans. See Phyllopod

apyretic.definition: Without fever; -- applied to days when there is an intermission of fever

apyrexia.definition: The absence or intermission of fever

apyrous.definition: Incombustible; capable of sustaining a strong heat without alteration of form or properties

aqua.definition: Water; -- a word much used in pharmacy and the old chemistry, in various signification, determined by the word or words annexed

aquaculture.definition: the cultivation of aquatic animals, such as fish or shellfish, or of plants, such as seaweed, in a controlled and sometimes enclosed body of water.  The term includes use of either salt or fresh water.  It is a form of agriculture, but under water

aqualung.definition: an apparatus containing compressed air or other oxygen-gas mixture, permitting a person to breathe under water; -- also called a scuba

aquamarine.definition: A transparent, pale green variety of beryl, used as a gem. See Beryl

aquapuncture.definition: The introduction of water subcutaneously for the relief of pain

aquarelle.definition: A design or painting in thin transparent water colors; also, the mode of painting in such colors

aquarellist.definition: A painter in thin transparent water colors

aquarial.definition: Of or pertaining to an aquarium

aquarian.definition: One of a sect of Christian in the primitive church who used water instead of wine in the Lord's Supper

aquarium.definition: An artificial pond, or a globe or tank (usually with glass sides), in which living specimens of aquatic animals or plants are kept

aquarius.definition: The Water-bearer; the eleventh sign in the zodiac, which the sun enters about the 20th of January; -- so called from the rains which prevail at that season in Italy and the East

aquatic.definition: Pertaining to water; growing in water; living in, swimming in, or frequenting the margins of waters; as, aquatic plants and fowls
Sports or exercises practiced in or on the water

aquatint.definition: A kind of etching in which spaces are bitten by the use of aqua fortis, by which an effect is produced resembling a drawing in water colors or India ink; also, the engraving produced by this method

aquavit.definition: a Scandinavian liquor usually flavored with caroway seeds; -- also called akvavit

aqueduct.definition: A conductor, conduit, or artificial channel for conveying water, especially one for supplying large cities with water
A canal or passage; as, the aqueduct of Sylvius, a channel connecting the third and fourth ventricles of the brain

aqueous.definition: Partaking of the nature of water, or abounding with it; watery
Made from, or by means of, water

aquifer.definition: an underground bed or layer yielding ground water for wells and springs etc.; as, the Oglala aquifer.  The water contained in an aquifer may be of great age, and in such cases is sometimes called fossil water

aquiferous.definition: Consisting or conveying water or a watery fluid; as, aquiferous vessels; the aquiferous system

aquifoliaceae.definition: a family of widely distributed shrubs and trees

aquila.definition: A northern constellation southerly from Lyra and Cygnus and preceding the Dolphin; the Eagle

aquilege.definition: a plant of the genus Aquilegia having irregular showy spurred flowers; N temperate regions esp. mountains

aquilegia.definition: a plant of the genus Aquilegia having irregular showy spurred flowers; N temperate regions esp. mountains

aquiline.definition: Belonging to or like an eagle
Curving; hooked; prominent, like the beak of an eagle; -- applied particularly to the nose

aquiparous.definition: Secreting water; -- applied to certain glands

aquitanian.definition: Of or pertaining to Aquitania, now called Gascony

aquosity.definition: The condition of being wet or watery; wateriness

ara.definition: The Altar; a southern constellation, south of the tail of the Scorpion
A name of the great blue and yellow macaw (Ara ararauna), native of South America

arab.definition: One of a swarthy race occupying Arabia, and numerous in Syria, Northern Africa, etc

araba.definition: A wagon or cart, usually heavy and without springs, and often covered

arabesque.definition: A style of ornamentation either painted, inlaid, or carved in low relief. It consists of a pattern in which plants, fruits, foliage, etc., as well as figures of men and animals, real or imaginary, are fantastically interlaced or put together
Relating to, or exhibiting, the style of ornament called arabesque; as, arabesque frescoes

arabesqued.definition: Ornamented in the style of arabesques

arabian.definition: Of or pertaining to Arabia or its inhabitants
A native of Arabia; an Arab

arabic.definition: Of or pertaining to Arabia or the Arabians

arabin.definition: A carbohydrate, isomeric with cane sugar, contained in gum arabic, from which it is extracted as a white, amorphous substance
Mucilage, especially that made of gum arabic

arabinose.definition: A sugar of the composition C5H10O5, obtained from cherry gum by boiling it with dilute sulphuric acid

arabism.definition: An Arabic idiom peculiarly of language

arabist.definition: One well versed in the Arabic language or literature; also, formerly, one who followed the Arabic system of surgery

arable.definition: Fit for plowing or tillage; -- hence, often applied to land which has been plowed or tilled

aracanese.definition: Of or pertaining to Aracan, a province of British Burmah

aracari.definition: A South American bird, of the genus Pleroglossius, allied to the toucans. There are several species

arace.definition: To tear up by the roots; to draw away

araceous.definition: Of or pertaining to an order of plants, of which the genus Arum is the type

arachnida.definition: One of the classes of Arthropoda. See Illustration in Appendix

arachnidial.definition: Of or pertaining to the Arachnida

arachnidium.definition: The glandular organ in which the material for the web of spiders is secreted

arachnoid.definition: Pertaining to a thin membrane of the brain and spinal cord, between the dura mater and pia mater
Covered with, or composed of, soft, loose hairs or fibers, so as to resemble a cobweb; cobwebby

arachnoidal.definition: Pertaining to the arachnoid membrane; arachnoid

arachnologist.definition: One who is versed in, or studies, arachnology

arachnology.definition: The department of Zoology which treats of spiders and other Arachnida

aragonese.definition: Of or pertaining to Aragon, in Spain, or to its inhabitants

aragonite.definition: A mineral composed of calcium carbonate and identical in composition with calcite, but differing from it in its crystalline form and some of its physical characters

araguato.definition: A South American monkey, the ursine howler (Mycetes ursinus). See Howler, n., 2

aralia.definition: any of various plants of the genus Aralia; often aromatic plants having compound leaves and small umbellate flowers

araliaceae.definition: a family of mostly tropical trees and shrubs and lianas: ginseng; hedera

aramaean.definition: Of or pertaining to the Syrians and Chaldeans, or to their language; Aramaic

aramaic.definition: Pertaining to Aram, or to the territory, inhabitants, language, or literature of Syria and Mesopotamia; Aramæan; -- specifically applied to the northern branch of the Semitic family of languages, including Syriac and Chaldee

aranea.definition: a genus of common garden spiders

araneae.definition: an order of arthropods constituting the spiders
synonyms: Syn. -- order Araneae, Araneida, order Araneida.

araneidal.definition: relating to or resembling a spider

araneidan.definition: Of or pertaining to the Araneina or spiders

araneiform.definition: Having the form of a spider

araneina.definition: The order of Arachnida that includes the spiders

araneose.definition: Of the aspect of a spider's web; arachnoid

araneous.definition: Cobweblike; extremely thin and delicate, like a cobweb; as, the araneous membrane of the eye. See Arachnoid

arango.definition: A bead of rough carnelian. Arangoes were formerly imported from Bombay for use in the African slave trade

arapaima.definition: A large fresh-water food fish of South America

arara.definition: The palm (or great black) cockatoo, of Australia (Microglossus aterrimus)

araroba.definition: A fabaceous tree of Brazil (Centrolobium robustum) having handsomely striped wood; -- called also zebrawood

araucaria.definition: A genus of tall conifers of the pine family. The species are confined mostly to South America and Australia. The wood cells differ from those of other in having the dots in their lateral surfaces in two or three rows, and the dots of contiguous rows alternating. The seeds are edible

araucariaceae.definition: a family of tall evergreen cone-bearing trees of South America and Australia with broad leathery leaves; in some classifications included in the Pinaceae

araucarian.definition: Relating to, or of the nature of, the Araucaria. The earliest conifers in geological history were mostly Araucarian

araujia.definition: small genus of South American evergreen vines

arawn.definition: Lord of Annwfn (the other world; land of fairies)

arb.definition: Someone who engages in arbitrage (who purchases securities in one market for immediate resale in another in the hope of profiting from the price differential); shortened form of arbitrageur

arbalest.definition: A crossbow, consisting of a steel bow set in a shaft of wood, furnished with a string and a trigger, and a mechanical device for bending the bow.  It served to throw arrows, darts, bullets, etc

arbiter.definition: A person appointed, or chosen, by parties to determine a controversy between them
Any person who has the power of judging and determining, or ordaining, without control; one whose power of deciding and governing is not limited

arbitrable.definition: Capable of being decided by arbitration; determinable

arbitrage.definition: Judgment by an arbiter; authoritative determination
A traffic in bills of exchange (see Arbitration of Exchange)
the simultaneous or near simultaneous purchase and sale of the same or closely linked securities or commodities in different markets to make a profit on the (often small) differences in price

arbitrageur.definition: someone who engages in arbitrage; i. e. one who purchases securities in one market for immediate resale in another in the hope of profiting from the price differential

arbitral.definition: Of or relating to an arbiter or an arbitration

arbitrarily.definition: In an arbitrary manner; by will only; despotically; absolutely

arbitrariness.definition: The quality of being arbitrary; despoticalness; tyranny

arbitrary.definition: Depending on will or discretion; not governed by any fixed rules; as, an arbitrary decision; an arbitrary punishment
Exercised according to one's own will or caprice, and therefore conveying a notion of a tendency to abuse the possession of power
Despotic; absolute in power; bound by no law; harsh and unforbearing; tyrannical; as, an arbitrary prince or government

arbitrate.definition: To hear and decide, as arbitrators; as, to choose to arbitrate a disputed case
To act as arbitrator or judge; as, to arbitrate upon several reports; to arbitrate in disputes among neighbors; to arbitrate between parties to a suit

arbitration.definition: The hearing and determination of a cause between parties in controversy, by a person or persons chosen by the parties

arbitrational.definition: relating to or resulting from arbitration

arbitrative.definition: of or pertaining to arbitration; relating to or having the authority to arbitrate

arbitrator.definition: A person, or one of two or more persons, chosen by parties who have a controversy, to determine their differences. See Arbitration
One who has the power of deciding or prescribing without control; a ruler; a governor

arbitratrix.definition: A female who arbitrates or judges

arbor.definition: A kind of latticework formed of, or covered with, vines, branches of trees, or other plants, for shade; a bower
A tree, as distinguished from a shrub
An axle or spindle of a wheel or opinion

arbor dianae.definition: A precipitation of silver, in a beautiful arborescent form

arbor vitae.definition: An evergreen tree of the cypress tribe, genus Thuja.  The American species is the Thuja occidentalis.  It is commonly used as an ornamental shrub around homes
The treelike disposition of the gray and white nerve tissues in the cerebellum, as seen in a vertical section

arborary.definition: Of or pertaining to trees; arboreal

arborator.definition: One who plants or who prunes trees

arboreal.definition: Of or pertaining to a tree, or to trees; of nature of trees
Attached to, found in or upon, or frequenting, woods or trees; as, arboreal animals

arbored.definition: Furnished with an arbor; lined with trees

arboreous.definition: Having the form, constitution, or habits, of a proper tree, in distinction from a shrub
Pertaining to, or growing on, trees; as, arboreous moss

arborescence.definition: The state of being arborescent; the resemblance to a tree in minerals, or crystallizations, or groups of crystals in that form; as, the arborescence produced by precipitating silver

arborescent.definition: Resembling a tree; becoming woody in stalk; dendritic; having crystallizations disposed like the branches and twigs of a tree

arboresque.definition: resembling a tree in form and branching structure
synonyms: Syn. -- arboreal, arboreous, arborescent, arboriform, dendriform, dendroid, dendroidal, treelike, tree-shaped.

arboretum.definition: A place in which a collection of rare trees and shrubs is cultivated for scientific or educational purposes

arboriculture.definition: The cultivation of trees and shrubs, chiefly for timber or for ornamental purposes

arborist.definition: One who makes trees his study, or who is versed in the knowledge of trees

arborization.definition: The appearance or figure of a tree or plant, as in minerals or fossils; a dendrite

arbuscle.definition: A dwarf tree, one in size between a shrub and a tree; a treelike shrub

arbuscular.definition: Of or pertaining to a dwarf tree; shrublike

arbustive.definition: Containing copses of trees or shrubs; covered with shrubs

arbutus.definition: The strawberry tree, a genus of evergreen shrubs, of the Heath family. It has a berry externally resembling the strawberry; the arbute tree

arc.definition: A portion of a curved line; as, the arc of a circle or of an ellipse
A curvature in the shape of a circular arc or an arch; as, the colored arc (the rainbow); the arc of Hadley's quadrant
The apparent arc described, above or below the horizon, by the sun or other celestial body. The diurnal arc is described during the daytime, the nocturnal arc during the night
To form a voltaic arc, as an electrical current in a broken or disconnected circuit

arc light.definition: The light of an arc lamp.  See arc lamp under lamp

arc-boutant.definition: A buttress that stands apart from the main structure and connected to it by an arch; same as flying buttress

arca.definition: the type genus of the family Arcidae, including ark shells and blood clams

arcade.definition: A series of arches with the columns or piers which support them, the spandrels above, and other necessary appurtenances; sometimes open, serving as an entrance or to give light; sometimes closed at the back (as in the cut) and forming a decorative feature
An arched or covered passageway or avenue

arcadia.definition: A mountainous and picturesque district of Greece, in the heart of the Peloponnesus, whose people were distinguished for contentment and rural happiness
Fig.: Any region or scene of simple pleasure and untroubled quiet

arcadian.definition: Of or pertaining to Arcadia; pastoral; ideally rural; as, Arcadian simplicity or scenery
the dialect of Ancient Greek spoken by Arcadians

arcanum.definition: A secret; a mystery; -- generally used in the plural

arcella.definition: An amoebalike protozoan with a chitinous shell resembling an umbrella

arcellidae.definition: A natural family of soil and freshwater protozoa; cosmopolitan

arceuthobium.definition: A genus of chiefly American plants parasitic on conifers

arch.definition: Any part of a curved line

Usually a curved member made up of separate wedge-shaped solids, with the joints between them disposed in the direction of the radii of the curve; used to support the wall or other weight above an opening.  In this sense arches are segmental, round (i. e., semicircular), or pointed
Any place covered by an arch; an archway; as, to pass into the arch of a bridge
Any curvature in the form of an arch; as, the arch of the aorta
To cover with an arch or arches
To form or bend into the shape of an arch
To form into an arch; to curve
Cunning or sly; sportively mischievous; roguish; as, an arch look, word, lad

arch brick.definition: A wedge-shaped brick used in the building of an arch

arch stone.definition: A wedge-shaped stone used in an arch; a voussoir

arch-.definition: A prefix signifying chief, as in archbuilder, archfiend

archaean.definition: Ancient; pertaining to the earliest period in geological history
The earliest period in geological period, extending up to the Lower Silurian. It includes an Azoic age, previous to the appearance of life, and an Eozoic age, including the earliest forms of life

archaeobacteria.definition: A group of single-celled microorganisms including the methanogens and some halophiles and thermoacidophiles, recognized in the 1970's by C. R. Woese and his colleagues as being a distinct group on the basis of RNA sequences, cell walls, and coenzymes differing from those of other microbes.  It is believed to be an ancient form of living organism that evolved separately from the eubacteria and blue-green algae.  It is classified as a separate kingdom by some taxonomists.  See also The Archaebacteria

archaeography.definition: A description of, or a treatise on, antiquity or antiquities

archaeolithic.definition: Of or pertaining to the earliest Stone age; -- applied to a prehistoric period preceding the Paleolithic age

archaeologic.definition: Relating to archæology, or antiquities; as, archæological researches

archaeologist.definition: One versed in archæology; an antiquary

archaeology.definition: The science or study of antiquities, esp. prehistoric antiquities, such as the remains of buildings or monuments of an early epoch, inscriptions, implements, and other relics, written manuscripts, etc

archaeopteryx.definition: A fossil bird, of the Jurassic period, remarkable for having a long tapering tail of many vertebræ with feathers along each side, and jaws armed with teeth, with other reptilian characteristics

archaeornis.definition: an extinct primitive toothed bird with a long feathered tail and three free clawed digits on each wing

archaeornithes.definition: a subclass of primitive reptilelike fossil birds of the Jurassic or early Cretaceous

archaeostomatous.definition: Applied to a gastrula when the blastopore does not entirely close up

archaeozoic.definition: Like or belonging to the earliest forms of animal life
formed in or belonging to the earlier of two divisions of the Precambrian era
the time from 1.5 billion to 5 billion years ago; the time when the earth's crust formed; a time when only unicellular organisms and the earliest forms of life are present
synonyms: Syn. -- Archeozoic, Archeozoic era, Archaeozoic era

archaic.definition: Of or characterized by antiquity or archaism; antiquated; obsolescent

archaism.definition: An ancient, antiquated, or old-fashioned, word, expression, or idiom; a word or form of speech no longer in common use
Antiquity of style or use; obsoleteness

archaistic.definition: Like, or imitative of, anything archaic; pertaining to an archaism

archaize.definition: To make appear archaic or antique

archangel.definition: A chief angel; one high in the celestial hierarchy
A term applied to several different species of plants (Angelica archangelica, Lamium album, etc.)

archangelic.definition: Of or pertaining to archangels; of the nature of, or resembling, an archangel

archbishop.definition: A chief bishop; a church dignitary of the first class (often called a metropolitan or primate) who superintends the conduct of the suffragan bishops in his province, and also exercises episcopal authority in his own diocese

archbishopric.definition: The jurisdiction or office of an archbishop; the see or province over which archbishop exercises archiepiscopal authority

archbutler.definition: A chief butler; -- an officer of the German empire

archchamberlain.definition: A chief chamberlain; -- an officer of the old German empire, whose office was similar to that of the great chamberlain in England

archchancellor.definition: A chief chancellor; -- an officer in the old German empire, who presided over the secretaries of the court

archdeacon.definition: In England, an ecclesiastical dignitary, next in rank below a bishop, whom he assists, and by whom he is appointed, though with independent authority

archdeaconry.definition: The district, office, or residence of an archdeacon. See Benefice

archducal.definition: Of or pertaining to an archduke or archduchy

archduchess.definition: The consort of an archduke; also, a princess of the imperial family of Austria. See Archduke

archduchy.definition: The territory of an archduke or archduchess

archduke.definition: A prince of the imperial family of Austria

archebiosis.definition: The origination of living matter from non-living. See Abiogenesis

arched.definition: Made with an arch or curve; covered with an arch; as, an arched door

archegoniate.definition: of or pertaining to an archegonium

archegonium.definition: The pistillidium or female organ in the higher cryptogamic plants, corresponding to the pistil in flowering plants

archelogy.definition: The science of, or a treatise on, first principles

archencephala.definition: The division that includes man alone

archenemy.definition: A principal enemy. Specifically, Satan, the grand adversary of mankind

archenteric.definition: Relating to the archenteron; as, archenteric invagination

archenteron.definition: The primitive enteron or undifferentiated digestive sac of a gastrula or other embryo. See Illust. under Invagination

archeologist.definition: an anthropologist who studies prehistoric people and their culture

archeology.definition: the branch of anthropology that studies prehistoric people and their cultures.  Same as Archæology, etc

archeopteryx.definition: an extinct primitive toothed bird (Archaeopteryx lithographica) of the Upper Jurassic having a long feathered tail and hollow bones; usually considered the most primitive of all known birds.  Same as archaeopteryx

archeozoic.definition: the time from 1.5 billion to 5 billion years ago, when the earth's crust was formed; the time when only unicellular organisms and the earliest forms of life are present.  Same as Archaeozoic
synonyms: Syn. -- Archaeozoic, Archeozoic era, Archaeozoic era

archepiscopal.definition: of or pertaining to an archbishop

archer.definition: A bowman, one skilled in the use of the bow and arrow

archer fish.definition: A small fish (Toxotes jaculator), of the East Indies; -- so called from its ejecting drops of water from its mouth at its prey. The name is also applied to Chætodon rostratus

archership.definition: The art or skill of an archer

archery.definition: The use of the bow and arrows in battle, hunting, etc.; the art, practice, or skill of shooting with a bow and arrows

archesporial.definition: of or pertaining to an archespore

archesporium.definition: a primitive cell or group of cells from which a mother cell develops

archetypal.definition: Of or pertaining to an archetype; consisting a model (real or ideal) or pattern; original

archetypally.definition: With reference to the archetype; originally. “Parts archetypally distinct.”

archetype.definition: The original pattern or model of a work; or the model from which a thing is made or formed
The standard weight or coin by which others are adjusted
The plan or fundamental structure on which a natural group of animals or plants or their systems of organs are assumed to have been constructed; as, the vertebrate archetype

archeus.definition: The vital principle or force which (according to the Paracelsians) presides over the growth and continuation of living beings; the anima mundi or plastic power of the old philosophers

archi-.definition: A prefix signifying chief, arch; as, architect, archiepiscopal. In (Biol.) and (Anat.) it usually means primitive, original, ancestral; as, archipterygium, the primitive fin or wing

archiannelida.definition: A group of Annelida remarkable for having no external segments or distinct ventral nerve ganglions

archiater.definition: Chief physician; -- a term applied, on the continent of Europe, to the first or body physician of princes and to the first physician of some cities

archibald wheel.definition: A metal-hubbed wheel of great strength and elasticity, esp. adapted for artillery carriages and motor cars

archiblastula.definition: A hollow blastula, supposed to be the primitive form; a cœloblastula

archidiaconal.definition: Of or pertaining to an archdeacon

archiepiscopacy.definition: That form of episcopacy in which the chief power is in the hands of archbishops
The state or dignity of an archbishop

archiepiscopal.definition: Of or pertaining to an archbishop; as, Canterbury is an archiepiscopal see

archiepiscopality.definition: The station or dignity of an archbishop; archiepiscopacy

archiepiscopate.definition: The office of an archbishop; an archbishopric

archierey.definition: The higher order of clergy in Russia, including metropolitans, archbishops, and bishops

archil.definition: A violet dye obtained from several species of lichen (Roccella tinctoria, etc.), which grow on maritime rocks in the Canary and Cape Verd Islands, etc
The plant from which the dye is obtained

archilochian.definition: Of or pertaining to the satiric Greek poet Archilochus; as, Archilochian meter

archimagus.definition: The high priest of the Persian Magi, or worshipers of fire
A great magician, wizard, or enchanter

archimandrite.definition: A chief of a monastery, corresponding to abbot in the Roman Catholic church

archimedean.definition: Of or pertaining to Archimedes, a celebrated Greek philosopher; constructed on the principle of Archimedes' screw; as, Archimedean drill, propeller, etc

archimedes.definition: Born at Syracuse about 287 b. c.: died at Syracuse, 212 b. c.  The most celebrated geometrician of antiquity.  He is said to have been a relative of King Hiero of Syracuse, to have traveled early in life in Egypt, and to have been the pupil of Conon the Samian at Alexandria.  His most important services were rendered to pure geometry, but his popular fame rests chiefly on his application of mathematical theory to mechanics.  He invented the water-screw, and discovered the principle of the lever. Concerning the latter the famous saying is attributed to him, "Give me where I may stand and I will move the world " (do`s pou^  stw^ kai` to`n ko`smos kinh`sw).  By means of military engines which he invented he postponed the fall of Syracuse when besieged by Marcellus 214-212 b. c., whose fleet he is incorrectly said to have destroyed by mirrors reflecting the sun's rays.  He detected the admixture of silver, and determined the proportions of the two metals, in a crown ordered by Hiero to be made of pure gold.  The method of detecting the alloy, without destroying the crown, occurred to him as he stepped in the bath and observed the overflow caused by the displacement of the water. He ran home through the street naked crying heureka, "I have found it."  He was killed at the capture of Syracuse by Marcellus
An extinct genus of Bryzoa characteristic of the subcarboniferous rocks. Its form is that of a screw

arching.definition: The arched part of a structure

archipallium.definition: the olfactory cortex of the cerebrum

archipelagic.definition: Of or pertaining to an archipelago

archipelago.definition: The Grecian Archipelago, or Ægean Sea, separating Greece from Asia Minor. It is studded with a vast number of small islands
Hence: Any sea or broad sheet of water interspersed with many islands or with a group of islands

archipterygium.definition: The primitive form of fin, like that of Ceratodus

architect.definition: A person skilled in the art of building; one who understands architecture, or makes it his occupation to form plans and designs of buildings, and to superintend the artificers employed

architective.definition: Used in building; proper for building

architectonic.definition: Pertaining to a master builder, or to architecture; evincing skill in designing or construction; constructive
Relating to the systemizing of knowledge
The act of arranging knowledge into a system

architectural.definition: Of or pertaining to the art of building; conformed to the rules of architecture

architecture.definition: The art or science of building; especially, the art of building houses, churches, bridges, and other structures, for the purposes of civil life; -- often called civil architecture
Construction, in a more general sense; frame or structure; workmanship

architeuthis.definition: A genus of gigantic cephalopods, allied to the squids, found esp. in the North Atlantic and about New Zealand

architrave.definition: The lower division of an entablature, or that part which rests immediately on the column, esp. in classical architecture. See Column

archival.definition: Pertaining to, or contained in, archives or records

archive.definition: The place in which public records or historic documents are kept
Public records or documents preserved as evidence of facts; as, the archives of a country or family

archives.definition: a collection of records especially about an institution
a place where historical records and documents are kept

archivist.definition: A keeper of archives or records

archivolt.definition: The architectural member surrounding the curved opening of an arch, corresponding to the architrave in the case of a square opening

archlute.definition: A large theorbo, or double-necked lute, formerly in use, having the bass strings doubled with an octave, and the higher strings with a unison

archly.definition: In an arch manner; with attractive slyness or roguishness; slyly; waggishly

archmarshal.definition: The grand marshal of the old German empire, a dignity that to the Elector of Saxony

archness.definition: The quality of being arch; cleverness; sly humor free from malice; waggishness

archon.definition: One of the chief magistrates in ancient Athens, especially, by preëminence, the first of the nine chief magistrates

archoplasm.definition: The substance from which attraction spheres develop in mitotic cell division, and of which they consist

archprelate.definition: An archbishop or other chief prelate

archpriest.definition: A chief priest; also, a kind of vicar, or a rural dean

archtreasurer.definition: A chief treasurer. Specifically, the great treasurer of the German empire

archway.definition: A way or passage under an arch

archy.definition: A suffix properly meaning a rule, ruling, as in monarchy, the rule of one only. Cf. -arch

arciform.definition: Having the form of an arch; curved

arcograph.definition: An instrument for drawing a circular arc without the use of a central point; a cyclograph

arctation.definition: Constriction or contraction of some natural passage, as in constipation from inflammation

arctic.definition: Pertaining to, or situated under, the northern constellation called the Bear; northern; frigid; as, the arctic pole, circle, region, ocean; an arctic expedition, night, temperature

arctiid.definition: a stout-bodied broad-winged moth with conspicuously striped or spotted wings; larvae are hairy caterpillars

arctiidae.definition: a family comprising the tiger moths

arctisca.definition: A group of Arachnida. See Illust. in Appendix

arctogeal.definition: Of or pertaining to arctic lands; as, the arctogeal fauna

arctoidea.definition: A group of the Carnivora, that includes the bears, weasels, etc

arctostaphylos.definition: a genus of plants including the bearberry; manzanita

arctotis.definition: a genus of herbs and subshrubs: African daisy

arcturus.definition: A fixed star of the first magnitude in the constellation Boötes

arcual.definition: Of or pertaining to an arc

arcuate.definition: Bent or curved in the form of a bow

arcuately.definition: In the form of a bow

arcuation.definition: The act of bending or curving; incurvation; the state of being bent; crookedness
A mode of propagating trees by bending branches to the ground, and covering the small shoots with earth; layering

arcubalister.definition: A crossbowman; one who used the arcubalist

ardassine.definition: A very fine sort of Persian silk

ardeidae.definition: a familu of wading birds incuding the herons, egrets, night herons, and bitterns

ardency.definition: Warmth of passion or affection; ardor; vehemence; eagerness; as, the ardency of love or zeal

ardennes.definition: a wooded plateau in the Champagne-Ardenne region of France; the site of intense fighting in World Wars I and II

ardent.definition: Hot or burning; causing a sensation of burning; fiery; as, ardent spirits, that is, distilled liquors; an ardent fever
Having the appearance or quality of fire; fierce; glowing; shining; as, ardent eyes
Warm, applied to the passions and affections; passionate; fervent; zealous; vehement; as, ardent love, feelings, zeal, hope, temper

ardent spirits.definition: any type of strongly alcoholic beverage prepared by distillation of an alcohol-containing fermented material

ardently.definition: In an ardent manner; eagerly; with warmth; affectionately; passionately

ardois system.definition: A widely used system of electric night signals in which a series of double electric lamps (white and red) is arranged vertically on a mast, and operated from a keyboard below

ardor.definition: Heat, in a literal sense; as, the ardor of the sun's rays
Warmth or heat of passion or affection; eagerness; zeal; as, he pursues study with ardor; the fought with ardor; martial ardor

arduous.definition: Steep and lofty, in a literal sense; hard to climb
Attended with great labor, like the ascending of acclivities; difficult; laborious; as, an arduous employment, task, or enterprise

arduously.definition: In an arduous manner; with difficulty or laboriousness

arduousness.definition: The quality of being arduous; difficulty of execution

are.definition: The present indicative plural of the substantive verb to be; but etymologically a different word from be, or was. Am, art, are, and is, all come from the root as
The unit of superficial measure, being a square of which each side is ten meters in length; 100 square meters, or about 119.6 square yards

area.definition: Any plane surface, as of the floor of a room or church, or of the ground within an inclosure; an open space in a building
The inclosed space on which a building stands
The sunken space or court, giving ingress and affording light to the basement of a building
An extent of surface; a tract of the earth's surface; a region; as, vast uncultivated areas
The superficial contents of any figure; the surface included within any given lines; superficial extent; as, the area of a square or a triangle
A spot or small marked space; as, the germinative area
Extent; scope; range; as, a wide area of thought

aread.definition: To tell, declare, explain, or interpret; to divine; to guess; as, to aread a riddle or a dream
To counsel, advise, warn, or direct

areal.definition: Of or pertaining to an area; as, areal interstices (the areas or spaces inclosed by the reticulate vessels of leaves)

arear.definition: To raise; to set up; to stir up
Backward; in or to the rear; behindhand

areca.definition: A genus of palms, one species of which (Areca catechu) produces the areca nut, or betel nut, which is chewed in India and Southeast Asia with the leaf of the Piper Betle and lime

arecidae.definition: one of four subclasses or superorder of Monocotyledones; comprises about 6400 species in 5 families of trees and shrubs and terrestrial herbs and a few free-floating aquatics including: Palmae; Araceae; Pandanaceae: and Lemnaceae

arecoline.definition: An oily liquid substance, C8H13O2N, the chief alkaloid of the betel nut, to which the latter owes its anthelmintic action
synonyms: Syn. -- arecholine; arecaline; methylarecaidin; methyl N-methyltetrahydronicotinate; 1,2,5,6-tetrahydro-1-methyl-3-pyridinecarboxylic acid methyl ester.

arefaction.definition: The act of drying, or the state of growing dry

arena.definition: The area in the central part of an amphitheater, in which the gladiators fought and other shows were exhibited; -- so called because it was covered with sand
Any place of public contest or exertion; any sphere of action; as, the arenaof debate; the arena of life

arenaceous.definition: Sandy or consisting largely of sand; of the nature of sand; easily disintegrating into sand; friable; as, arenaceous limestone

arenation.definition: A sand bath; application of hot sand to the body

arendator.definition: In some provinces of Russia, one who farms the rents or revenues

areng.definition: A palm tree (Saguerus saccharifer) which furnishes sago, wine, and fibers for ropes; the gomuti palm

arenicolite.definition: An ancient wormhole in sand, preserved in the rocks

arenicolous.definition: growing or living or burrowing in sand

arenilitic.definition: Of or pertaining to sandstone; as, arenilitic mountains

arenulous.definition: Full of fine sand; like sand

areola.definition: An interstice or small space, as between the cracks of the surface in certain crustaceous lichens; or as between the fibers composing organs or vessels that interlace; or as between the nervures of an insect's wing
The colored ring around the nipple, or around a vesicle or pustule

areolar.definition: Pertaining to, or like, an areola; filled with interstices or areolæ

areolate.definition: Divided into small spaces or areolations, as the wings of insects, the leaves of plants, or the receptacle of compound flowers

areolation.definition: Any small space, bounded by some part different in color or structure, as the spaces bounded by the nervures of the wings of insects, or those by the veins of leaves; an areola

areolet.definition: A small inclosed area; esp. one of the small spaces on the wings of insects, circumscribed by the veins

areometer.definition: An instrument for measuring the specific gravity of fluids; a form hydrometer

areometric.definition: Pertaining to, or measured by, an areometer

areometry.definition: The art or process of measuring the specific gravity of fluids

areopagus.definition: The highest judicial court at Athens. Its sessions were held on Mars' Hill. Hence, any high court or tribunal

arest.definition: A support for the spear when couched for the attack

aret.definition: To reckon; to ascribe; to impute

aretaics.definition: The ethical theory which excludes all relations between virtue and happiness; the science of virtue; -- contrasted with eudemonics

arete.definition: An acute and rugged crest of a mountain range or a subsidiary ridge between two mountain gorges

aretology.definition: That part of moral philosophy which treats of virtue, its nature, and the means of attaining to it

argal.definition: A ludicrous corruption of the Latin word ergo, therefore
A species of wild sheep (Ovis ammon, or Ovis argali), remarkable for its large horns.  It inhabits the mountains of Siberia and central Asia

argand lamp.definition: A lamp with a circular hollow wick and glass chimney which allow a current of air both inside and outside of the flame

argas.definition: A genus of venomous ticks which attack men and animals.  The famous Persian Argas, also called Miana bug, is Argas Persicus; that of Central America, called talaje by the natives, is Argas Talaje

argean.definition: Pertaining to the ship Argo. See Argo

argent.definition: The white color in coats of arms, intended to represent silver, or, figuratively, purity, innocence, beauty, or gentleness; -- represented in engraving by a plain white surface
Made of silver; of a silvery color; white; shining

argental.definition: Of or pertaining to silver; resembling, containing, or combined with, silver

argentalium.definition: A (patented) alloy of aluminium and silver, with a density of about 2.9

argentamine.definition: A solution of silver phosphate in an aqueous solution of ethylene diamine, used as an antiseptic astringent and as a disinfectant

argentan.definition: An alloy of nickel with copper and zinc; German silver

argentation.definition: A coating or overlaying with silver

argentic.definition: Pertaining to, derived from, or containing, silver; -- said of certain compounds of silver in which this metal has its lowest proportion; as, argentic chloride

argentiferous.definition: Producing or containing silver; as, argentiferous lead ore or veins

argentina.definition: a country in South America, bordering Chile and Bolivia
type genus of the Argentinidae: argentines

argentine.definition: Pertaining to, or resembling, silver; made of, or sounding like, silver; silvery
Of or pertaining to the Argentine Republic in South America
A siliceous variety of calcite, or carbonate of lime, having a silvery-white, pearly luster, and a waving or curved lamellar structure
A fish of Europe (Maurolicus Pennantii) with silvery scales. The name is also applied to various fishes of the genus Argentina
A citizen of the Argentine Republic; an Argentinian
Argentina; in this sense, usually preceded by the

argentinian.definition: of or pertaining to Argentina or its inhabitants
a native or inhabitant of Argentina

argentinidae.definition: a family of small marine soft-finned fishes with long silvery bodies; related to salmons and trouts

argentite.definition: Sulphide of silver; -- also called vitreous silver, or silver glance. It has a metallic luster, a lead-gray color, and is sectile like lead

argentous.definition: Of, pertaining to, or containing, silver; -- said of certain silver compounds in which silver has a higher proportion than in argentic compounds; as, argentous chloride

argil.definition: Clay, or potter's earth; sometimes pure clay, or alumina. See Clay

argillaceous.definition: Of the nature of clay; consisting of, or containing, argil or clay; clayey

argilliferous.definition: Producing clay; -- applied to such earths as abound with argil

argillite.definition: Argillaceous schist or slate; clay slate. Its colors is bluish or blackish gray, sometimes greenish gray, brownish red, etc

argillo-areenaceous.definition: Consisting of, or containing, clay and sand, as a soil

argillo-calcareous.definition: Consisting of, or containing, clay and calcareous earth

argive.definition: Of or performance to Argos, the capital of Argolis in Greece

argo.definition: The name of the ship which carried Jason and his fifty-four companions to Colchis, in quest of the Golden Fleece
A large constellation in the southern hemisphere, called also Argo Navis. In modern astronomy it is replaced by its three divisions, Carina, Puppis, and Vela

argol.definition: Crude tartar; an acidulous salt from which cream of tartar is prepared. It exists in the juice of grapes, and is deposited from wines on the sides of the casks

argolic.definition: Pertaining to Argolis, a district in the Peloponnesus

argon.definition: A colorless, odorless gas occurring in the air (of which it constitutes 0.93 per cent by volume), in volcanic gases, etc.; -- so named on account of its inertness by Rayleigh and Ramsay, who prepared and examined it in 1894-95. Symbol, A; at. wt., 39.9. Argon is condensible to a colorless liquid boiling at -186.1° C. and to a solid melting at -189.6° C. It has a characteristic spectrum. No compounds of it are known, but there is physical evidence that its molecule is monatomic. Weight of one liter at 0° C. and 760 mm., 1.7828 g

argonaut.definition: Any one of the legendary Greek heroes who sailed with Jason, in the Argo, in quest of the Golden Fleece
A cephalopod of the genus Argonauta
One of those who went to California in search of gold shortly after it was discovered there in 1848

argonauta.definition: A genus of Cephalopoda. The shell is called paper nautilus or paper sailor

argonautic.definition: Of or pertaining to the Argonauts

argonautidae.definition: a family of cephalopods represented solely by the genus Argonauta

argonne.definition: an American operation in World War I (1918); American troops under Pershing drove back the German armies which were saved only by the Armistice on November 11
synonyms: Syn. -- Meuse, Meuse River, Argonne Forest, Meuse-Argonne, Meuse-Argonne operation

argos.definition: an ancient city in SE Greece; dominated the Peloponnese in the 7th century BC

argosy.definition: A large ship, esp. a merchant vessel of the largest size

argot.definition: A secret language or conventional slang peculiar to thieves, tramps, and vagabonds; flash

arguable.definition: Capable of being argued; admitting of debate

argue.definition: To invent and offer reasons to support or overthrow a proposition, opinion, or measure; to use arguments; to reason
To contend in argument; to dispute; to reason; -- followed by with; as, you may argue with your friend without convincing him
To debate or discuss; to treat by reasoning; as, the counsel argued the cause before a full court; the cause was well argued
To prove or evince; too manifest or exhibit by inference, deduction, or reasoning
To persuade by reasons; as, to argue a man into a different opinion
To blame; to accuse; to charge with

arguer.definition: One who argues; a reasoner; a disputant

argulus.definition: A genus of copepod Crustacea, parasitic of fishes; a fish louse. See Branchiura

argument.definition: A reason or reasons offered in proof, to induce belief, or convince the mind; reasoning expressed in words; as, an argument about, concerning, or regarding a proposition, for or in favor of it, or against it
A process of reasoning, or a controversy made up of rational proofs; argumentation; discussion; disputation
The subject matter of a discourse, writing, or artistic representation; theme or topic; also, an abstract or summary, as of the contents of a book, chapter, poem
Matter for question; business in hand
The quantity on which another quantity in a table depends; as, the altitude is the argument of the refraction
The independent variable upon whose value that of a function depends
To make an argument; to argue

argumental.definition: Of, pertaining to, or containing, argument; argumentative

argumentation.definition: The act of forming reasons, making inductions, drawing conclusions, and applying them to the case in discussion; the operation of inferring propositions, not known or admitted as true, from facts or principles known, admitted, or proved to be true

argumentative.definition: Consisting of, or characterized by, argument; containing a process of reasoning; as, an argumentative discourse
Adductive as proof; indicative; as, the adaptation of things to their uses is argumentative of infinite wisdom in the Creator
Given to argument; characterized by argument; disputatious; as, an argumentative writer

argus.definition: A fabulous being of antiquity, said to have had a hundred eyes, who has placed by Juno to guard Io.  His eyes were transplanted to the peacock's tail
One very vigilant; a guardian always watchful

A genus of East Indian pheasants. The common species (Argus giganteus) is remarkable for the great length and beauty of the wing and tail feathers of the male.  The species Argus Grayi inhabits Borneo

argus shell.definition: A species of shell (Cypræa argus), beautifully variegated with spots resembling those in a peacock's tail

argyreia.definition: a genus of woody climbers of tropical Asia to Australia

argyrol.definition: a compound of protein and silver used as a mild antiseptic; Argyrol is the trademark

argyrotaenia.definition: a genus comprising the orange tortrix

argyroxiphium.definition: a small genus of Hawaiian spreading and rosette-forming shrubs

arhant.definition: a Buddhist who has attained nirvana

arhat.definition: a Buddhist who has attained nirvana

aria.definition: An air or song; a melody; a tune

arian.definition: Pertaining to Arius, a presbyter of the church of Alexandria, in the fourth century, or to the doctrines of Arius, who held Christ to be inferior to God the Father in nature and dignity, though the first and noblest of all created beings

arianize.definition: To admit or accept the tenets of the Arians; to become an Arian

arianrod.definition: a goddess famous for her beauty; the mother of Dylan

aricine.definition: An alkaloid, first found in white cinchona bark

arid.definition: Exhausted of moisture; parched with heat; dry; barren

aridity.definition: The state or quality of being arid or without moisture; dryness
Fig.: Want of interest of feeling; insensibility; dryness of style or feeling; spiritual drought

ariel.definition: A variety of the gazelle (Antilope dorcas, or Gazella, dorcas), found in Arabia and adjacent countries
In the Cabala, a water spirit; in later folklore, a light and graceful spirit of the air

aries.definition: The Ram; the first of the twelve signs in the zodiac, which the sun enters at the vernal equinox, about the 21st of March

arietation.definition: The act of butting like a ram; act of using a battering-ram

aright.definition: Rightly; correctly; in a right way or form; without mistake or crime; as, to worship God aright

aril.definition: A exterior covering, forming a false coat or appendage to a seed, as the loose, transparent bag inclosing the seed of the white water lily. The mace of the nutmeg is also an aril

arillode.definition: A false aril; an aril originating from the micropyle instead of from the funicle or chalaza of the ovule. The mace of the nutmeg is an arillode

ariocarpus.definition: a genus of slow-growing geophytic cacti; northern and eastern Mexico; southern Texas

arion.definition: In Greek legend, a fabulous horse, the offspring of Poseidon by Demeter (or, in other accounts, Gaea or a harpy) who to escape him had metamorphosed herself into a mare. It was successively owned by Copreus, Oncus, Heracles, and Adrastus. It possessed marvelous powers of speech, and its right feet were those of a man

ariose.definition: Characterized by melody, as distinguished from harmony

arioso.definition: In the smooth and melodious style of an air; ariose

arisarum.definition: a genus of tuberous or rhizomatous perennial herbs; mainly Mediterranean area

arise.definition: To come up from a lower to a higher position; to come above the horizon; to come up from one's bed or place of repose; to mount; to ascend; to rise; as, to arise from a kneeling posture; a cloud arose; the sun ariseth; he arose early in the morning

To spring up; to come into action, being, or notice; to become operative, sensible, or visible; to begin to act a part; to present itself; as, the waves of the sea arose; a persecution arose; the wrath of the king shall arise
To proceed; to issue; to spring

arist.definition: 3d sing. pres. of Arise, for ariseth

aristate.definition: Having a pointed, beardlike process, as the glumes of wheat; awned
Having a slender, sharp, or spinelike tip

aristocracy.definition: A ruling body composed of the best citizens
A form a government, in which the supreme power is vested in the principal persons of a state, or in a privileged order; an oligarchy
The nobles or chief persons in a state; a privileged class or patrician order; (in a popular use) those who are regarded as superior to the rest of the community, as in rank, fortune, or intellect

aristocrat.definition: One of the aristocracy or people of rank in a community; one of a ruling class; a noble
One who is overbearing in his temper or habits; a proud or haughty person
One who favors an aristocracy as a form of government, or believes the aristocracy should govern

aristocratic.definition: Of or pertaining to an aristocracy; consisting in, or favoring, a government of nobles, or principal men; as, an aristocratic constitution
Partaking of aristocracy; befitting aristocracy; characteristic of, or originating with, the aristocracy; as, an aristocratic measure; aristocratic pride or manners

aristolochiaceae.definition: a family comprising the birthworts; wild ginger

aristolochiales.definition: an order of plants distinguished by tubular petaloid perianth and inferior ovary.  It includes the Aristolochiaceae, Rafflesiaceae, and Hydnoraceae

aristophanic.definition: Of or pertaining to Aristophanes, the Athenian comic poet

aristotelean.definition: of or pertaining to Aristotle; Aristotelian

aristotelia.definition: a small genus of shrubs or small trees of Australia and New Zealand and West South America

aristotelian.definition: Of or pertaining to Aristotle, the famous Greek philosopher (384-322 b. c.)

aristotelianism.definition: The philosophy of Aristotle, otherwise called the Peripatetic philosophy

aristotelic.definition: Pertaining to Aristotle or to his philosophy

aristotle's lantern.definition: The five united jaws and accessory ossicles of certain sea urchins

aristotype.definition: Orig., a printing-out process using paper coated with silver chloride in gelatin; now, any such process using silver salts in either collodion or gelatin; also, a print so made

aristulate.definition: Having a short beard or awn

arithmetic.definition: The science of numbers; the art of computation by figures
A book containing the principles of this science

arithmetical.definition: Of or pertaining to arithmetic; according to the rules or method of arithmetic

arithmetically.definition: Conformably to the principles or methods of arithmetic

ark.definition: The oblong chest of acacia wood, overlaid with gold, which supported the mercy seat with its golden cherubs, and occupied the most sacred place in the sanctuary. In it Moses placed the two tables of stone containing the ten commandments. Called also the Ark of the Covenant
The large, chestlike vessel in which Noah and his family were preserved during the Deluge. Gen. vi. Hence: Any place of refuge
A large flatboat used on Western American rivers to transport produce to market

ark shell.definition: A marine bivalve shell belonging to the genus Arca and its allies

arkose.definition: A sandstone derived from the disintegration of granite or gneiss, and characterized by feldspar fragments

arles.definition: An earnest; earnest money; money paid to bind a bargain

arm.definition: The limb of the human body which extends from the shoulder to the hand; also, the corresponding limb of a monkey
Fig.: Power; might; strength; support; as, the secular arm; the arm of the law
A branch of the military service; as, the cavalry arm was made efficient
To take by the arm; to take up in one's arms
To furnish with arms or limbs
To furnish or equip with weapons of offense or defense; as, to arm soldiers; to arm the country
To cover or furnish with a plate, or with whatever will add strength, force, security, or efficiency; as, to arm the hit of a sword; to arm a hook in angling
Fig.: To furnish with means of defense; to prepare for resistance; to fortify, in a moral sense
To provide one's self with arms, weapons, or means of attack or resistance; to take arms

armada.definition: A fleet of armed ships; a squadron. Specifically, the Spanish fleet which was sent to assail England, a. d. 1558

armadillidiidae.definition: a family comrising the pill bugs

armadillidium.definition: the type genus of the Armadillidiidae

armadillo.definition: Any edentate animal if the family Dasypidæ, peculiar to America. The body and head are incased in an armor composed of small bony plates. The armadillos burrow in the earth, seldom going abroad except at night. When attacked, they curl up into a ball, presenting the armor on all sides. Their flesh is good food. There are several species, one of which (the peba) is found as far north as Texas. See Peba, Poyou, Tatouay

armageddon.definition: the final, decisive battle between the forces of good and evil, as foretold in the Apocolypse of Saint John.  Also, the site of that battle.  Used metaphorically for a vast and decisive conflict, attended by cataclysmic destruction

armament.definition: A body of forces equipped for war; -- used of a land or naval force
All the cannon and small arms collectively, with their equipments, belonging to a ship or a fortification

armamentary.definition: An armory; a magazine or arsenal

armature.definition: Armor; whatever is worn or used for the protection and defense of the body, esp. the protective outfit of some animals and plants

A piece of soft iron used to connect the two poles of a magnet, or electro-magnet, in order to complete the circuit, or to receive and apply the magnetic force. In the ordinary horseshoe magnet, it serves to prevent the dissipation of the magnetic force
Iron bars or framing employed for the consolidation of a building, as in sustaining slender columns, holding up canopies, etc

That moving part of a dynamo or electric generator in which a current is induced by a moving through a magnetic field, or, in an electric motor, the part through which the applied current moves, thereby generating torque. The armature usually consists of a series of coils or groups of insulated conductors surrounding a core of iron

armband.definition: a band worn around arm as identification or to indicate mourning
a band worn around the upper arm

armchair.definition: A chair with arms to support the elbows or forearms

armed.definition: Furnished with weapons of offense or defense; furnished with the means of security or protection
Furnished with whatever serves to add strength, force, or efficiency
Having horns, beak, talons, etc; -- said of beasts and birds of prey

armenia.definition: a country in the Caucasus, formerly a part of the Soviet Union

armenian.definition: A native or one of the people of Armenia; also, the language of the Armenians
An adherent of the Armenian Church, an organization similar in some doctrines and practices to the Greek Church, in others to the Roman Catholic

armeria.definition: a genus of shrubby or herbaceous low-growing evergreen perennials

armet.definition: A kind of helmet worn in the 14th, 15th, and 16th centuries

armful.definition: As much as the arm can hold

armhole.definition: The cavity under the shoulder; the armpit
A hole for the arm in a garment

armiger.definition: Formerly, an armor bearer, as of a knight, an esquire who bore his shield and rendered other services. In later use, one next in degree to a knight, and entitled to armorial bearings. The term is now superseded by esquire

armilla.definition: A ring of hair or feathers on the legs

armillary.definition: Pertaining to, or resembling, a bracelet or ring; consisting of rings or circles

arming.definition: The act of furnishing with, or taking, arms
A piece of tallow placed in a cavity at the lower end of a sounding lead, to bring up the sand, shells, etc., of the sea bottom
Red dress cloths formerly hung fore and aft outside of a ship's upper works on holidays

arminian.definition: Of or pertaining to Arminius of his followers, or to their doctrines. See note under Arminian, n
One who holds the tenets of Arminius, a Dutch divine (b. 1560, d. 1609)

arminianism.definition: The religious doctrines or tenets of the Arminians

armipotent.definition: Powerful in arms; mighty in battle

armisonant.definition: Rustling in arms; resounding with arms

armistice.definition: A cessation of arms for a short time, by convention; a temporary suspension of hostilities by agreement; a truce

armlet.definition: A small arm; as, an armlet of the sea
An arm ring; a bracelet for the upper arm

armor.definition: Defensive arms for the body; any clothing or covering worn to protect one's person in battle
Steel or iron covering, whether of ships or forts, protecting them from the fire of artillery

armor-bearer.definition: One who carries the armor or arms of another; an armiger

armor-clad.definition: protected with a covering of armor

armor-plated.definition: Covered with defensive plates of metal, as a ship of war; steel-clad

armored cruiser.definition: A man-of-war carrying a large coal supply, and more or less protected from the enemy's shot by iron or steel armor. There is no distinct and accepted classification distinguishing armored and protected cruisers from each other, except that the first have more or heavier armor than the second

armored division.definition: a division of a land army which is equipped with armored vehicles such as tanks or armored personnel carriers

armorer.definition: One who makes or repairs armor or arms
Formerly, one who had care of the arms and armor of a knight, and who dressed him in armor
One who has the care of arms and armor, cleans or repairs them, etc

armorial.definition: Belonging to armor, or to the heraldic arms or escutcheon of a family

armoric.definition: Of or pertaining to the northwestern part of France (formerly called Armorica, now Bretagne or Brittany), or to its people

armorist.definition: One skilled in coat armor or heraldry

armory.definition: A place where arms and instruments of war are deposited for safe keeping
A manufactory of arms, as rifles, muskets, pistols, bayonets, swords
That branch of heraldry which treats of coat armor

armoured.definition: provided with protective covering; -- used of animals.  Opposite of unarmored
same as armor-clad; -- used of persons or things military.  Opposite of unarmored

armourer.definition: an enlisted man responsible for the upkeep of small arms and machine guns etc

armoury.definition: all the weapons and equipment that a country has
a military structure where arms and ammunition and other military equipment are stored and training is given in the use of arms
a place where arms are manufactured

armozeen.definition: A thick plain silk, generally black, and used for clerical

armpit.definition: The hollow beneath the junction of the arm and shoulder; the axilla

armrack.definition: A frame, generally vertical, for holding small arms

arms.definition: Instruments or weapons of offense or defense
The deeds or exploits of war; military service or science
Anything which a man takes in his hand in anger, to strike or assault another with; an aggressive weapon
The ensigns armorial of a family, consisting of figures and colors borne in shields, banners, etc., as marks of dignity and distinction, and descending from father to son
The legs of a hawk from the thigh to the foot

armure.definition: A variety of twilled fabric ribbed on the surface

army.definition: A collection or body of men armed for war, esp. one organized in companies, battalions, regiments, brigades, and divisions, under proper officers
A body of persons organized for the advancement of a cause; as, the Blue Ribbon Army
A great number; a vast multitude; a host

army organization.definition: The system by which a country raises, classifies, arranges, and equips its armed land forces. The usual divisions are: (1) A regular or active army, in which soldiers serve continuously with the colors and live in barracks or cantonments when not in the field; (2) the reserves of this army, in which the soldiers, while remaining constantly subject to a call to the colors, live at their homes, being summoned more or less frequently to report for instruction, drill, or maneuvers; and (3) one or more classes of soldiers organized largely for territorial defense, living at home and having only occasional periods of drill and instraction, who are variously called home reserves (as in the table below), second, third, etc., line of defense (the regular army and its reserves ordinarily constituting the first line of defense), territorial forces, or the like. In countries where conscription prevails a soldier is supposed to serve a given number of years.  He is usually enrolled first in the regular army, then passes to its reserve, then into the home reserves, to serve until he reaches the age limit. It for any reason he is not enrolled in the regular army, he may begin his service in the army reserves or even the home reserves, but then serves the full number of years or up to the age limit. In equipment the organization of the army is into the three great arms of infantry, cavalry, and artillery, together with more or less numerous other branches, such as engineers, medical corps, etc., besides the staff organizations such as those of the pay and subsistence departments

armyworm.definition: A lepidopterous insect, which in the larval state often travels in great multitudes from field to field, destroying grass, grain, and other crops. The common army worm of the northern United States is the noctuid moth (Pseudaletia unipuncta, formerly Leucania unipuncta. The name is often applied to other related species, as the cotton worm
the larva of the fungus gnat; -- they march in large companies in regular order

arna.definition: The wild buffalo of India (Bos, or Bubalus, arni), larger than the domestic buffalo and having enormous horns

arnaut.definition: An inhabitant of Albania and neighboring mountainous regions, specif. one serving as a soldier in the Turkish army

arnica.definition: A genus of plants; also, the most important species (Arnica montana), native of the mountains of Europe, used in medicine as a narcotic and stimulant

arnicin.definition: An active principle of Arnica montana. It is a bitter resin

arnicine.definition: An alkaloid obtained from the arnica plant

aroid.definition: Belonging to, or resembling, the Arum family of plants (Araceae)
Any plant of the Arum family (Araceæ); -- have small flowers massed on a spadix surrounded by a large spathe

aroint.definition: To drive or scare off by some exclamation

aroma.definition: The quality or principle of plants or other substances which constitutes their fragrance; agreeable odor; as, the aroma of coffee
Fig.: The fine diffusive quality of intellectual power; flavor; as, the subtile aroma of genius

aromatic.definition: Pertaining to, or containing, aroma; fragrant; spicy; strong-scented; odoriferous; as, aromatic balsam
A plant, drug, or medicine, characterized by a fragrant smell, and usually by a warm, pungent taste, as ginger, cinnamon, spices

aromatization.definition: The act of impregnating or secting with aroma

aromatize.definition: To impregnate with aroma; to render aromatic; to give a spicy scent or taste to; to perfume

aromatizer.definition: One who, or that which, aromatizes or renders aromatic

aroph.definition: A barbarous word used by the old chemists to designate various medical remedies

arose.definition: The past or preterit tense of Arise

around.definition: In a circle; circularly; on every side; round
In a circuit; here and there within the surrounding space; all about; as, to travel around from town to town
Near; in the neighborhood; as, this man was standing around when the fight took place
On all sides of; encircling; encompassing; so as to make the circuit of; about
From one part to another of; at random through; about; on another side of; as, to travel around the country; a house standing around the corner

around-the-clock.definition: proceeding without interruption for twenty four hours every day
synonyms: Syn. -- day-and-night, nonstop, round-the-clock, twenty four hours a day.

arousal.definition: The act of arousing, or the state of being aroused

arouse.definition: To excite to action from a state of rest; to stir, or put in motion or exertion; to rouse; to excite; as, to arouse one from sleep; to arouse the dormant faculties

aroused.definition: brought to a state of great psychological tension
stimulated to a state of awareness and interest
sexually aroused; feeling a strong urge for sexual activity
synonyms: Syn. -- aflame, hot, turned on(predicate), horny.

aroused.definition: excessively affected by emotion; -- of persons

arow.definition: In a row, line, or rank; successively; in order

arpeggio.definition: The production of the tones of a chord in rapid succession, as in playing the harp, and not simultaneously; a strain thus played

arpent.definition: Formerly, a measure of land in France, varying in different parts of the country. The arpent of Paris was 4,088 sq. yards, or nearly five sixths of an English acre. The woodland arpent was about 1 acre, 1 rood, 1 perch, English

arpentator.definition: The Anglicized form of the French arpenteur, a land surveyor

arquated.definition: Shaped like a bow; arcuate; curved

arquebus.definition: A sort of hand gun or firearm a contrivance answering to a trigger, by which the burning match was applied. The musket was a later invention

arquebusade.definition: A distilled water from a variety of aromatic plants, as rosemary, millefoil, etc.; -- originally used as a vulnerary in gunshot wounds

arquebusier.definition: A soldier armed with an arquebus

arrack.definition: A name in the East Indies and the Indian islands for all ardent spirits. Arrack is often distilled from a fermented mixture of rice, molasses, and palm wine of the cocoanut tree or the date palm, etc

arraign.definition: To call or set as a prisoner at the bar of a court to answer to the matter charged in an indictment or complaint
To call to account, or accuse, before the bar of reason, taste, or any other tribunal
Arraignment; as, the clerk of the arraigns
To appeal to; to demand; as, to arraign an assize of novel disseizin

arraignment.definition: The act of arraigning, or the state of being arraigned; the act of calling and setting a prisoner before a court to answer to an indictment or complaint
A calling to an account to faults; accusation

arrange.definition: To put in proper order; to dispose (persons, or parts) in the manner intended, or best suited for the purpose; as, troops arranged for battle
To adjust or settle; to prepare; to determine; as, to arrange the preliminaries of an undertaking

arranged.definition: disposed or placed in a particular kind of order
having a schedule and itinerary established prior to departure; -- of travel plans

arrangement.definition: The act of arranging or putting in an orderly condition; the state of being arranged or put in order; disposition in suitable form
The manner or result of arranging; system of parts disposed in due order; regular and systematic classification; as, arrangement of one's dress; the Linnæan arrangement of plants
Preparatory proceeding or measure; preparation; as, we have made arrangement for receiving company
Settlement; adjustment by agreement; as, the parties have made an arrangement between themselves concerning their disputes; a satisfactory arrangement
The adaptation of a composition to voices or instruments for which it was not originally written

arranging.definition: the act of arranging a piece of music

arrant.definition: Notoriously or preëminently bad; thorough or downright, in a bad sense; shameless; unmitigated; as, an arrant rogue or coward
Thorough or downright, in a good sense

arrantly.definition: Notoriously, in an ill sense; infamously; impudently; shamefully

arras.definition: Tapestry; a rich figured fabric; especially, a screen or hangings of heavy cloth with interwoven figures

arrasene.definition: A material of wool or silk used for working the figures in embroidery

arrastre.definition: A rude apparatus for pulverizing ores, esp. those containing free gold

arraswise.definition: Placed in such a position as to exhibit the top and two sides, the corner being in front; -- said of a rectangular form

array.definition: Order; a regular and imposing arrangement; disposition in regular lines; hence, order of battle; as, drawn up in battle array
The whole body of persons thus placed in order; an orderly collection; hence, a body of soldiers
Dress; garments disposed in order upon the person; rich or beautiful apparel
A ranking or setting forth in order, by the proper officer, of a jury as impaneled in a cause
To place or dispose in order, as troops for battle; to marshal
To deck or dress; to adorn with dress; to cloth to envelop; -- applied esp. to dress of a splendid kind
To set in order, as a jury, for the trial of a cause; that is, to call them man by man

arrayer.definition: One who arrays. In some early English statutes, applied to an officer who had care of the soldiers' armor, and who saw them duly accoutered

arrear.definition: To or in the rear; behind; backwards

That which is behind in payment, or which remains unpaid, though due; esp. a remainder, or balance which remains due when some part has been paid; arrearage; -- commonly used in the plural, as, arrears of rent, wages, or taxes

arrearage.definition: That which remains unpaid and overdue, after payment of a part; arrears

arrenotokous.definition: Producing males from unfertilized eggs, as certain wasps and bees

arrentation.definition: A letting or renting, esp. a license to inclose land in a forest with a low hedge and a ditch, under a yearly rent

arreptitious.definition: Snatched away; seized or possessed, as a demoniac; raving; mad; crack-brained

arrest.definition: To stop; to check or hinder the motion or action of; as, to arrest the current of a river; to arrest the senses
To take, seize, or apprehend by authority of law; as, to arrest one for debt, or for a crime
To seize on and fix; to hold; to catch; as, to arrest the eyes or attention
To rest or fasten; to fix; to concentrate
The act of stopping, or restraining from further motion, etc.; stoppage; hindrance; restraint; as, an arrest of development
The taking or apprehending of a person by authority of law; legal restraint; custody. Also, a decree, mandate, or warrant
Any seizure by power, physical or moral
A scurfiness of the back part of the hind leg of a horse; -- also named rat-tails

arrestee.definition: The person in whose hands is the property attached by arrestment

arrester.definition: The person at whose suit an arrestment is made

arrestment.definition: The arrest of a person, or the seizure of his effects; esp., a process by which money or movables in the possession of a third party are attached

arret.definition: A judgment, decision, or decree of a court or high tribunal; also, a decree of a sovereign

arrha.definition: Money or other valuable thing given to evidence a contract; a pledge or earnest

arrhizal.definition: Destitute of a true root, as a parasitical plant

arrhythmic.definition: Being without rhythm or regularity, as the pulse

arriere.definition: “That which is behind”; the rear; -- chiefly used as an adjective in the sense of behind, rear, subordinate

arriere-ban.definition: A proclamation, as of the French kings, calling not only their immediate feudatories, but the vassals of these feudatories, to take the field for war; also, the body of vassals called or liable to be called to arms, as in ancient France

arris.definition: The sharp edge or salient angle formed by two surfaces meeting each other, whether plane or curved; -- applied particularly to the edges in moldings, and to the raised edges which separate the flutings in a Doric column

arrish.definition: The stubble of wheat or grass; a stubble field; eddish

arrival.definition: The act of arriving, or coming; the act of reaching a place from a distance, whether by water (as in its original sense) or by land
The attainment or reaching of any object, by effort, or in natural course; as, our arrival at this conclusion was wholly unexpected
The person or thing arriving or which has arrived; as, news brought by the last arrival

arrive.definition: To come to the shore or bank. In present usage: To come in progress by water, or by traveling on land; to reach by water or by land; -- followed by at (formerly sometimes by to), also by in and from
To reach a point by progressive motion; to gain or compass an object by effort, practice, study, inquiry, reasoning, or experiment
To come; said of time; as, the time arrived

arriving.definition: directed or moving inward or toward a center; as, arriving trains
